In like manner this epithet is applied to thunder, and to a cloud or rain accompanied with thunder; in each case after the manner of a rel. n. (TA.)

hom.sense:
lajobapN and lujobapN↓ and lijobapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and lajabapN↓ [but see what is said respecting the last of the pls. mentioned below] and lajibapN↓ and lijabapN↓ (Ḳ) the last two from Th. (TA.) A sheep or goat (XAp, Ḳ), or a sheep only, not a goat, (ISk, Ṣ,) of which the milk has become little in quantity: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a sheep or goat (XAp) which has passed four months since her bringing forth, and of which the milk has in consequence dried up: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or it is an epithet applied specially to a goat: (Ḳ:) a poet (Muhelhil, TA,) says,
Eajibato OabonaAWunaA mino fiEolinaA
Uico nabiyEu Alxayola biAlmiEozaI All-ijaAbo
[Our sons wondered at our action, in our selling horses for goats of which the milk had become little, or dried up]: (Ṣ:) and contr., abounding with milk: (Ḳ:) a poet applies the two epithets lajobap and HaAXikap to the same sheep or goat; but he may mean that her milk was little at one time, and abundant at another. (TA.) Pl. [of lajobapN] lijaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and lajobaAtN (this being allowed by Mbr, agreeably with analogy, TA) and lajabaAtN (Ṣ, Ḳ): the last dev. with respect to rule; for by rule it should be lajobaAtN; unless it be originally a subst. used as an epithet, like as one says UimoraOapN kalobapN; or unless lajabapN↓ be a syn. of the sing. (Ṣ.) Sb says, that lajabaAtN is used as pl. because some of the Arabs used lajabapN↓ as sing. (TA.)

All-jb [app. All-ajabu, a quasi-pl. n.,] occurring in the following words of a trad., fayaboduw OamovaAlu Alljbi mina Alc-ahabi, is said to be pl. of lajobapN: or it is All-ijabu, like as qiSaEN is pl. of qaSoEapN. (TA.)

In a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, according to one reading, occur the words, bljbtI AlbAbi: but Aboo-Moosà says, that the right reading is with f [instead of the b, and with I before it: i. e. bilajiyfataI AlbAb: see art. ljf]. (TA.)

entry.sense: lujobapN: see lajobapN.
lijobapN: see lajobapN.
lajabapN: see lajobapN.
lajibapN: see lajobapN.
lajabapN: see lajobapN.
milojaAbN An arrow feathered, but without the point: (Ḳ:) pl. malaAjiybu. (TA.) minojaAbN is the more common word; and the l appears to be substituted for the n. (ISd.)

lujoHN A thing in the lower part of a well, and of a valley, like what is called a daHol: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, in the lower part of a well, and of a mountain, like a naqob: (L:) originally luHojN, from which it is formed by transposition: (T:) pl. OalojaAHN. (L.)

dictScrap.label: See art. ljc.

entry.sense: 1. lajaca, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yalojucu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lajocN; (L, Ḳ;) and lajica, aor. _a {yalojacu}; (Ḳ;) He ate (L, Ḳ) food. (L.)
He (a beast) began to pasture. (L, Ḳ.)

He (a beast) ate herbage: (L:) you say, when beasts have eaten herbage, lujica AlkalaOu: (Ṣ, L:) or ate it with the extremity of his tongue, (L, Ḳ,) it being such as did not allow him to take it with his teeth: (L:) accord. to Aṣ, lajacahu signifies i. q. las-ahu [he plucked it with the fore part of his mouth.] (Ṣ, L.)

He licked: in this sense, the inf. n. is lajocN and lajacN: (Ḳ:) you say, lajica Alkalobu AlUinaMCa, inf. n. lajocN and lajacN, the dog licked the vessel (AḤát, Ṣ, Ḳ) inside: (L:) [J says,] I have transcribed it from the Kitáb el-Abwáb, without having heard it: (Ṣ:) and lajica Alkalobu the dog put his tongue into a vessel and lapped; as also lajida and lajina. (AA, L.)
He took little. (L, Ḳ.)

He asked often after having been given once: (Ḳ:) lajacaniI, aor. _u {yalojucu}, inf. n. lajocN, signifies he asked me, and did so much, after I had given him: (Ṣ:) or he asked me after he had asked me and I had given him: (AZ, L:) or he asked me, and did so much, after he had asked me and I had given him. (Aṣ, L.)
He instigated; incited; excited. (Ḳ.)
lijaAcN Glue; syn. giraMCN [for which Freytag seems to have read UigoraMCN]. (Ḳ.)
daAb-apN milojaAcN A beast of carriage that takes the leguminous herbage with the fore part of its mouth, (Ḳ,) and the extremities of its teeth. (TA.)
nbotN majoluwcN A plant which the teeth cannot crop, by reason of its shortness, and which the camels therefore pluck with the fore part of the mouth. (L.)

dictScrap.title: ljf / ljm / ljn
dictScrap.label:
[ljf, ljm and ljn
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. laHiHato Eayonuhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. taloHaHu, inf. n. laHaHN; (L;) and laH-ato; (L;) [as also laxixato:] His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, by reason of pain: or, by reason of many tears: (L:) the former is one of those verbs which retain their original forms, like Dabiba in the phrase Dabiba Albaladu, with the reduplication distinct: (Ṣ:) also, laH-ato Eayonuhu his eye shed many tears, and its lids became thick, or rough; like lax-ato. (L.)
laH-ati AlqaraAbapu bayonanaA, inf. n. laH-N, The relationship between us was close. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.) See laH-N.
4. AlH-, (inf. n. UiloHaAHN, Mṣb,) It [a cloud] rained continually, or incessantly. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) Hence the phrase AlH- ElI XI [q. v. infra]. (Mṣb)

AlH- Ealoyhi, (inf. n. UiloHaAHN, L,) He importuned him; plied him; plied him hard; pressed him; pressed upon him; pressed him hard; was urgent with him; persecuted, or harassed, him, (L,) biQlomasoOalapi, (Ṣ, L,) or fiI Als-aWaAli, (Ḳ,) in asking, begging, or petitioning; like OaloHafa. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) AlH- ElI gariymihi He pressed his creditor perseveringly, assiduously, or constantly. (L.) And OaloHaHotu EalaI fulaAnK fiI AlAit-ibaAEi Hat-aI Qxotalafotuh, i. e. [I pressed upon such a one in following] until I made him to be behind me. (ISk, TA in art. xlf.) AlH- EalaI XaIoCK [and fiI XaIoCK] He applied himself to a thing perseveringly, persistently, assiduously, or constantly, (Mṣb,) or incessantly. (L.) AlH- fiI XaIoCK He asked, begged, or petitioned, for a thing much, or frequently; as though he stuck to it. (L.) AlH- EalaI gay-ihi [and fI gay-ihi He persevered, or persisted, in his error]. (Mṣb, art. mdI.)
It (a cloud) remained, or stayed, bimakaAnK in a place; like Oalav-a. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)

AlH- ‡ He (a camel) was restive, or refractory, and would not move from his place; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) like as you say of a she-camel xalaOato, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) and of a horse and the like Hazana: (Aṣ:) and AlH-t she (a camel) did the same; (L, Ḳ;) accord. to some, and so used in a trad. (TA.)
AlH-ti AlmaTiI-u ‡ The beasts of carriage, or the camels, were fatigued, and became slow, or tardy. (Ḳ.)
AlH- ‡ It (a saddle of the kind called qatab, L, Ḳ, and a raHol, and a horse's saddle, L) wounded the back. (L, Ḳ.) See miloHaAHN.
R. Q. 1. laHolaHuwA, (Ḳ,) and talaHolaHuwA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) They remained fixed, or firm, in their place; did not quit it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
talaHolaHa↓ He (a camel) stayed, and remained fixed, or firm. (L.)
Also tlHlHwA↓ They became dispersed; formed by transposition from tHlHlwA. (L.)
R. Q. 2: See R. Q. 1.

huwa Qbonu Eam-iI laH-FA [He is my cousin on the father's side,] closely related: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from the phrase laHiHato Eayonuhu. (Ṣ.) Here lH-A is put in the acc. case as a denotative of state, because what precedes it is determinate. (Ṣ.) And you say huwa Qbonu Eam-K laH-K [He is a cousin on the father's side,] closely related, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in an indeterminate phrase employing laH-K as an epithet to Eam-K. (Ṣ.) You say the same in the case of the fem. and dual and pl.; (Ṣ;) making no difference between the sing. and dual and pl. and fem. (L.) Lḥ says, that one says, [of two persons who are cousins, one to the other,] humaA QbonaA Eam-K laH-K, and laH-FA; and in like manner hmA AbnA xaAlapK; but not hmA AbnA xaAlK laH-FA, nor AbnA Eam-apK laH-FA. (L.) When the Abn Em- is not in the state termed laH-, but is of the EaXiyrap, you say huwa Qbonu Eam-i AlkalaAlapi, and Abnu Eam-K kalaAlapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also dinoyFA; and the contr., ZohrFA.]
laHiHN and laHolaHN: see laAH-N.

laAH-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and laHiHN↓ and laHolaHN↓ (Ḳ) A strait, or confined, place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Also, laAH-N, A valley with tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated, trees, which stick together: or strait, or confined, and abounding with tangled trees, and stones. In both senses, applied to a place and a valley, it is also written laAx-N, with x. (L.) [See laAx-N.]
OalaH-u [More, and most, importunate, pressing, persevering,, &c.]. (TA, art. xnfs; see the same article in the present work.)
muliH-N That stands still by reason of fatigue, and will not move from its place. (TA.)
A beast of carriage which, when it lies down, remains immovable, and will not be roused up. (L.)
miloHaAHN A cloud continually, or incessantly, raining. (L.)
A man [very] importunate, pressing, persevering, assiduous, or constant, in asking, begging, petitioning, or seeking. (L.)
raHFI miloHaAHN EalaI maA taToHanuhu (Ṣ) A mill-stone that presses hard upon that which it grinds. (A.)

miloHaAHN ‡ A saddle of the kind called qatab that wounds the back; (Ḳ;) that wounds the camel's withers; (Ṣ;) that sticks close to the camel's back, and wounds it; and in like manner a saddle of the kind called raHol, and a horse's saddle. (L.)
Whatever is slow, or tardy. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. laHaba, aor. _a {yaloHabu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. laHobN; (Ṣ;) and AltHb↓; (Ḳ;) He trod, and passed along, a road, such as is termed laHobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or simply, a road. (TA.) So also AltHm. (Lth.)
laHabahu and lH-bh↓ He smote him with a sword: (Ḳ:) or wounded him with it. (Th.)
laHabahu and lH-bh↓ He made a mark, or impression, upon it. (Ḳ.)
He flogged him with whips, and made marks, or scars, upon him. (TA.)
laHabahu, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He cut it (i. e. flesh-meat) lengthwise. (Ḳ.)
laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He stripped off meat from the bone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He (a butcher) took what was on the back of the slaughtered camel. (TA.)
He peeled a stick or the like, (Ṣ,) or anything. (TA.)
It (the portion next the back-bone, on either side, of a horse, (Ḳ,) or his rump, TA) was smooth, and sloping downwards: syn. UimolaOas-a fiI HuduwrK. (Ḳ.)
laHaba, aor. _a {yaloHabu}, inf. n. luHuwbN, It (a road) became conspicuous, clear, or open: (Ḳ:) as though it peeled [the surface of] the ground. (TA.)

laHaba, inf. n. laHobN, He made a road conspicuous, or clear. (Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying of Umm-Selmeh to ʼOthmán, laA tuEaf-i TariyqFA kaAna rasuwlu Qll-ehi SlEm laHabahaA Do not thou efface a road which the Apostle of God, &c., made conspicuous, or clear. (TA.)
laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) † Inivit feminam. (Ḳ.) See laxaba.
laHaba bih AlOaroDa He threw him down prostrate upon the ground. (Ḳ.)
laHaba, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He (a man) passed, or went along, through the land: (TA:) or he went right on, or straight on: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he hastened in his pace; went quickly. (Ḳ.)
laHiba, aor. _a {yaloHabu}, [inf. n. laHabN,] He (a man) became emaciated by reason of old age, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and weakness. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
8: see 1.

laHobN and laAHibN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ: the latter word of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: i. e. maloHuwbN: Ṣ) and mulaH-abN↓ (Ḳ) A conspicuous road: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a wide, extended, road, that is not interrupted. (TA.)

laHiybN A she-camel having little flesh in her back: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) originally, it seems, in the sense of maloHuwb, as though meaning “peeled” by travel; and afterwards, its original attributive character being forgotten among a people, used without p [when not preceded by the noun which it qualifies, as when preceded by that noun]. (TA.)
laAHibN: see laHobN.
miloHabN Anything with which a thing is cut or peeled: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) cutting, or sharp, iron. (TA.)
† A great reviler, or vilifier, of obscene tongue. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† A chaste, or an eloquent, tongue. (T.)
maloHuwbN Smooth, and sloping downwards: an epithet applied to the portion next the back-bone, on either side, [or to the rump,] of a horse. (TA.) [See an ex. voce quSobN.]
A man of little flesh; emaciated: as though peeled. (TA.)
mulaH-abN Cut in pieces: syn. muqaT-aEN. (Ṣ.)
See laHobN.

hom.sense: 1. laHata, aor. _a {yaloHatu}, (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, a person with a staff, or stick. (Ḳ.)
laHata, aor. _a {yaloHatu}, (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He peeled, or unbarked, a staff, or stick: (Ḳ:) or sawed it, and peeled, or unbarked it: as also naHata. (IAạr.)

hecaA rajulN laA yaDiyruka Ealayohi naHotFA walaHotFA expl. by mA yzydk Elyh nHtA AllXEr wlHtA lh ‡ [This is a man than whom none will be more useful to thee in the trimming of verses: yDyrk, which is written without the syll. points, is probably a mistake for yaDur-uka: see art. Dr]. (IAạr.)
laHatahu biAlEacoli, aor. _a {yaloHatu}, inf. n. laHotN, [He trimmed him with reproof]: a phrase similar to that immediately preceding. (TA, app. from IAạr.)
laHatahu, aor. _a {yaloHatu}, inf. n. laHotN, † He took what he had, leaving him nothing; as also lataHahu. (TA.)
laHata Inivit puellam: as also naHata, but this latter is not so well known. (TA, art. nHt.)

entry.sense: barodN baHotN laHotN i. q. SaAdiqN; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) [i.e., Vehement, or intense, cold: see baHotN: and see also laxotN]. laHotN is here a mere imitative sequent. (TA.)
1. laHija aor. _a {yaloHaju}, (inf. n. laHajN, Ṣ,) It (a sword, Ṣ, Ḳ, or other thing, Ṣ) stuck fast in the scabbard, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and would not come forth; like laSiba. (Ṣ.)
laHija AlxaAtamu fiI AlUiSobaEi The sealring stuck fast upon his finger. (A.)
laHija bayonahumu AlX-ar-u Evil stuck fast between, or among, them. (TA.)
laHija bimakaAnK He clave fast to a place; kept fast, or close, to it. (TA.)
laHija fiI AlOamori He entered into an affair and became entangled in it so that he could not extricate himself. (TA.)

laHaja Uilayohi, aor. _a {yaloHaju}, inf. n. laHojN; and AltHj↓; He inclined to him, or it. (TA.) By the following words of Ru-beh,
Oawo taloHaju AlOalosunu min-aA maloHajaA
is meant, Or tongues speak of us, and incline from what is good to that which is bad. (L.) [For mnhA, in the L, I have substituted mn-A. mlHj seems to be an inf. n.]
laHaja Uilayohi, [and AltHj↓, Golius, from Ibn-Maạroof,] He had recourse to him or it for protection or concealment. (Ḳ.)
laHija It (a thing) became strait, narrow, or confined. (TA.)

2. lH-j Ealayohi Alxabara, inf. n. taloHiyjN; and laHowajahu↓ Ealayohi, inf. n. laHowajapN; He rendered the news, or information, confused to him, and told him something different from that which was in his mind: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the phrase with the former verb signifies he told him news, or a piece of information, different * from that which was in his mind; and that with the latter verb, he rendered the news, or information, confused to him. (Az.) See 5.
4. AlHjhu Uilayohi, He caused him to incline to him, or it. (TA.)
AlHjhu Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) and AltHjhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or to do, it, (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tlH-j Ealayohi AlOamora, and laHowajahu↓ Elyh, He represented the affair to him not as it was in his mind. (L.) See 2.
8. UilotaHaja see 1 and 4.
10. AstlHj AlbaAba [app. He found the door stuck fast]: (A:) [but I think it not improbable that the right reading is AlbaAbu; and the meaning, the door stuck fast].
Q. Q. 1. laHowaja: see 2 and 5.
luHojN: see lujoHN.
laHijN A strait, narrow, or confined, place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maloHajN (Ḳ) and mulotaHajN↓ (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) A place to which one has recourse for protection or concealment; a place of refuge; an asylum. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
malaAHiju Strait, narrow, or confined, places. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
malaAHiyju Narrow roads in mountains. (TA.)
xuT-apN maloHuwjapN A confused and crooked business. (L.)
qufolN mulaH-ajN A lock that is not [or, app., that cannot be] opened. (A.)
mulotaHajN see maloHajN.

hom.sense: 1. laHada (A) and AlHd↓ (L, Ḳ) ‡ He, or it, (as an arrow, A) declined, or deviated, from the right course: (A, L, Ḳ:) and also he, or it, inclined: you say laHada Uilayohi, (A, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaloHadu}; (L;) and AlHd↓ (A;) and AltHd↓; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) he, or it, inclined to him, or it. (A, L, Ḳ.) Some read, [in the Ḳur xvi. 105,] lisaAnu Ql-aciI yaloHaduwna Uilayohi ‡ [The tongue of him unto whom they incline]. (Ṣ.)

AlHd↓ fiI Ald-iyni; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb;) and laHada fiyhi, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaloHadu}; (L;) ‡ He deviated, or swerved, from the right way, with respect to religion: (Ṣ, A, L:) he impugned religion. (Mṣb.)

AlHd↓ fiI AlHarami ‡ He relinquished, or forsook, the right course, with respect to that which he was commanded to do, in the sacred Temple or territory of Mekkeh; (L, Ḳ;) and inclined to do wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously: (L:) or he did wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, therein; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and so opposed others: (Fr, L:) or he associated others with God, therein; expl. by OaXoraka biQll-ehi: so in the Ḳ and Basáïr; in the latter as on the authority of Zj: or he doubted respecting God, therein: so in the L and other lexicons, as on the authority of Zj: (TA:) or he hoarded up corn in expectation of its becoming dear, therein; (L, Ḳ;) a meaning taken from a trad of ʼOmar; (L;) but this is merely a kind of wrong-doing: (TA:) or he desecrated it, and violated its sanctity. (Mṣb.) The origin of the phrase is in the text of the Ḳur [xx. 26,] wamano yurido fiyhi biUiloHaAdK biZulomK, i.e. UiloHaAdFA biZulomK, the b being redundant. (Ṣ, L.)
laHada Alqabora, aor. _a {yaloHadu}, (inf. n. laHodN; L,) and AlHdhu↓; (A, L, Ḳ;) and laHada lahu laHodFA; and AlHd↓ lh; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) He made a laHod to the grave. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. lAHdhu † He behaved towards him in a crooked, or perverse, manner, the latter doing the same. (Ḳ,* TA.)
4. AlHd: see 1, throughout.
† He disputed; altercated; wrangled. (A' Obeyd, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

AlHd bihi † He brought a reproach upon him, or held him in light estimation, or despised him, (OazoraI bihi,) and said of him what was false: (Ḳ:) or he held his clemency, or forbearance, or intellect, (Hilom,) in light estimation; or despised it; as also Oalohada bihi. (L.)
8. AltHd Uilayohi ‡ He had recourse, or betook himself, to it, or him, for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging. (A.)

laHodN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and luHodN↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and laHadN↓ (El-Basáïr) and maloHuwdN↓, (A, L, Ḳ,) which last is an epithet wherein the quality of a subst. is predominant, (L,) A trench or an oblong excavation, in the side of a grave; a lateral hollow of a grave; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which is the place of the corpse; what is called DariyHN and DariyHapN is in the middle: (L:) pl. (of the first, Mṣb) luHuwdN and (of the second, Mṣb) OaloHaAdN. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Accord. to some, lHd used in this sense is tropical; from laHada and OaloHada signifying “he inclined, or declined.” (MF.) [The reverse, however, is the case accord. to the A.] [See an ex. in a verse cited voce XadiydN.]
luHodN and laHadN: see laHodN.
laAHidN: see maloHuwdN.

muloHidN act. part. n. of 4, q. v.: ‡ One who deviates, or swerves, from the truth, and introduces into it that which does not belong to it: (ISk, L:) an impugner of religion: (Mṣb in art. rndq;) pl. muloHiduwna (Mṣb) [and malaAHicapN]. Some apply the appellation of AlmuloHiduwna especially to the Bátinees (AlbaATiniy-ap), who assert that the Ḳur-án has an outward sense and an inward, the latter differing from the former, and known to them; by which doctrine they have perverted the law. (Mṣb.)
muloHadN: see maloHuwdN.
maloHuwdN (A, Ḳ) and muloHadN↓, (Ṣ, A,) or maloHuwdN lahu and muloHadN↓ lahu, (L,) and laAHidN↓, (Ḳ,) A grave having a laHod made to it. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
See laHodN.
mulotaHadN ‡ A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging: a place of refuge; an asylum: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because one turns aside to it. (Ṣ.)

1. laHisahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or laHisahu bilisaAnihi, (A,) aor. _a {yaloHasu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. laHosN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maloHasN (A Ḳ) and laHosapN and luHosapN, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last mentioned by ISk, (TA,) He licked it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) namely, a bowl, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a vessel: (Ṣ:) All-aHosu is with the tongue: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
or laHsahu signifies he took what was upon it, (Mgh,) or what adhered to its sides, (Mṣb,) with his tongue or his finger; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the suffixed pronoun referring to a bowl (Mgh, Mṣb) or some other thing: (Mgh:) and he took it (a thing) with his tongue. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, OasoraEu mino laHosi Alkalobi Oanofahu [Quicker than the dog's licking his nose]. (Ṣ, A.) See also maloHasN, below.

laHisa Ald-uwdu AlS-uwfa, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) in measure like labisa, (Mgh,) or laHasa, like manaEa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. laHosN, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The worms ate the wool: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner, lHs AljaraAdu AlxuDara (A, Ḳ) and AlX-ajara, (TA,) the locusts ate the green plants (Ḳ) and the trees. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AlHst AlOaroDu ‡ The land produced plants, or herbage: (Ṣ:) or began to produce leguminous plants: (Ḳ:) or produced the first of the herbage, so that the beasts saw it and desired it and licked it, not being able to eat of it anything: (TA:) or produced what the beasts of carriage might lick or eat (maA taloHasuhu): (A, TA:) or [became in such a state that] the beasts of carriage licked or ate (laHasato) its plants, or herbage. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
AlHs AlmaAXiyapa ‡ He pastured the camels or sheep or goats with the least pasturing. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. AltHs minohu Haq-ahu ‡ He took from him his (the former's, A) right, or due. (A, Ḳ.)
laHosapN: see 1. [Accord. to analogy, it is an inf. n. of un.]
luHosapN [The quantity that one takes by one lick with the tongue. Hence the saying,] maA laka EinodiI luHosapN I have not anything for thee, or belonging to thee. (TA.)
See also 1.
laHuwsN: see miloHasN.
laHowasN: see miloHasN.
laH-aAsN A man who licks much what comes to him. (TA.)
laH-aAsapN A moth-worm, that eats wool; syn. Euv-apN. (TA.)
A lioness. (Ḳ.)

sanapN laAHisapN ‡ A distressful, or calamitous, year; (Ḳ;) a year that consumes all the herbage: (A, TA:) and lawaAHisu, [the pl., sinuwnN, being understood,] distressful, or calamitous, years. (A, TA.)
laAHuwsN: see miloHasN.

maloHasN is a noun of place; [signifying A place of licking;, &c.;] as well as an inf. n.: and in both cases it has malaAHisu for pl. (IJ.) You say, tarakotuhu bimalaA Hisi Albaqari, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or bimalaAHisi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA, (TA,) meaning, ‡ I left him in the places where the wild cows lick their young ones (Ṣ, ISd, A, Ḳ) from the membranes in which they are born: (ISd, TA:) or in a desert place, (Ṣ,) or in a desert, or waterless desert, (ISd, A, TA,) so that it was not known where he was; (Ṣ;) because the wild cows bring forth only in the deserts: (ISd, TA:) the former is like the saying bimabaAHivi Albaqari; (Ṣ;) and is that which ISd holds to be the right: (TA:) in the latter, mlAHs is an inf. n., in the pl. form, which is strange; because it governs AwlAd in the accus. case; and a prefixed noun [mawaADiE] is understood before it: (IJ:) some relate the saying differently, thus, bimaloHasi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA, meaning, bimawoDiEi maloHasi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA [in the place of the cows' licking their young ones]; (Ḳ;) because [some hold that] an inf. n. of the measure mafoEalN has no pl. (TA.)
muloHisN: see miloHasN.

miloHasN ‡ Greedy; as also laHowas↓ (Ḳ) and laAHuwsN↓ and muloHisN↓: (TA:) and one who takes everything that he can. (Ḳ:) or a greedy man, who takes everything that he can: (A:) one who takes everything that appears to him: (TA:) [originally, a lick-dish:] and [in like manner] laHuwsN↓ ‡ a man who seeks after sweets, like the fly. (A, Ḳ.)
Also, † Courageous: (Ḳ:) as though an eater of everything that rose up to him. (TA.)
2. lH-Shu see lx-Shu.

1. laHaZahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or laHaZahu biAlEayoni, (Mṣb,) and laHaZa Uilayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaloHaZu}, inf. n. laHoZN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and laHaZaAnN, (Ḳ,) He looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to the right or left, (Mṣb, TA,) with more turning of the face than is denoted by XazorN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or without turning the face: (TA:) or he watched him with the eye: (Mṣb:) and hence mulaAHaZapN↓, of the measure mufaAEalapN, (Ḳ, TA,) explained by Az as signifying a man's looking from the outer angle of either eye. (TA.)
3. lAHZhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. mulaAHaZapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and liHaAZN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [i. q. laHaZahu, q. v.]
[And hence,] ‡ He regarded him; had regard, or an eye, to him; paid regard, or consideration, to him; he regarded it, [namely, an affair,] or attended to it; syn. raAEaAhu. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
[And † He, or it, had a relation, or an analogy, to him, or it.]
6. tlAHZwA (TA) They turned their eyes, [each looking from the outer angle of his eye,] one towards another. (Ḳ, L.)
[And hence, † They regarded one another; had regard, or an eye, one to another; paid regard, or consideration, one to another.]
[And † They had a mutual relation, or analogy.]
laHoZN: see laHaAZN.

laHoZapN A look from the outer angle of the eye; a sidelong glance; an ogle; a look from the side next the ear: pl. laHaZaAtN: the dim. is luHayoZapN. (TA.) Hence the saying jalasotu Einodahu laHoZapF I sat with him the like of [the time occupied by] a look from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) And fiI laHoZapK [In the twinkling of an eye]. (Ḳ in art. srE;, &c.)

laHaAZN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like saHaAbN, (Ḳ,) or liHaAZN↓, (T, IB, Mgh, Mṣb,) with kesr, (T, IB, Mṣb,) which latter is the form commonly known, (IB,) or the latter is incorrectly used for the former by some who twist the sides of the mouth in utterance, (MF,) or is [only] an inf. n. of laAxaZa, (Ṣ,) The outer angle of the eye, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) next the part between the eye and the ear; (T, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also laHoZN↓: pl. of the former luHuZN: and of the latter OaloHaAZN. (TA.) You say, fatanatohu bilaHaAZihaA [She captivated his heart with the outer angle of her eye], and biOaloHaAZihaA [with the outer angles of her eyes]. (TA.)
liHaAZN: see laHaAZN.
laHiyZN † Like. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa laHiyZu fulaAnK. † He is the like of such a one. (TA.)
rajulN laH-aAZN [A man who has a habit of looking from the outer angle of the eye]. (TA.)
syn. with [the inf. n.] laHoZN: or it signifies mawoDiEu laHoZK [i.e. the place at which one looks from the outer angle of the eye]: pl. malaAHiZu. (TA.)
[maloHuwZN † Regarded; had in view.]
OaHowaAluhumo mutaXaAkilapN mutalaAHiZapN ‡ [Their states, or conditions, are similar; such as have mutual relation, or analogy]. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: lHf / lHq / lHk / lHm / lHn / lHI
dictScrap.label:
[lHf, lHq, lHk, lHm, lHn and lHI
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. lax-ato Eayonuhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. talix-N, inf. n. lax-N and laxiyxN, (L,) His eye shed copious tears, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and its lids became rough. (L.)
laxixato Eayonuhu, as also laHiHato, His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners. (L.) See lH-.
lax-a fiI kalaAmihi, [aor., accord. to analogy, _i,] He was obscure and barbarous in his speech. (Ḳ.)
8. Altx- Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo Their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
Altx- It (herbage) became tangled, or luxuriant. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: lax-apN Obscureness and barbarousness in speech. (TA.)
A dirty, stinking, woman. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jawofN lAx-N A deep valley. (IAạr.)

laxolaxaAniI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) fem. with p {laxolaxaAniy-apN}, (L,) A man whose speech, or utterance, is characterized by what is termed laxolaxaAniy-ap, or barbarousness, or vitiousness, &c.: (L:) not chaste in speech, or utterance. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

laxolaxaAniy-apN A barbarousness, or vitiousness, in speech, or utterance; a want of chasteness therein; an impotence, or impediment, or a difficulty, therein. (AO, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) It is a quality of the dial. of the Arabs of the desert of Esh-Shahr and 'Omán; as when they say, for maA XaMCa Qll-ehu, maXaMCa Qll-ehu: (Eth-Tha'álibee:) or is derived from laxolaxaAnu, the name of a tribe: or, as some say, of a place. (L.) naZara fulaAnN naZara All-axaloxaAniy-api Such a one looked with the look of barbarians, or foreigners; or, of those who are barbarous in speech. (Aṣ.)

sakoraAnu mulotax-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) vulg. muloTax-N, (Ṣ,) or mulaT-axN, (as in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ,) but this should not be said, (Ḳ,) A drunken man confused in his intellect, (Ṣ, L,) and not understanding anything: (L:) or, full of drink; (Ḳ;) as also murotax-N. (TA in art. rx.)
See laAx-N.

hom.sense: 1. laxaba He slapped a person; struck him with the open hand. (Ḳ.)
laxaba, aor. _a {yaloxabu} and _u {yaloxubu}, (inf. n. laxobN, TA,) Inivit feminam: (Kr, Ḳ:) but the word commonly known, related by Yaạḳoob and others, is naxaba. (ISd.)

entry.sense: 3. lAxbhu, inf. n. mulaAxabapN (and lixaAbN, TA), He slapped him, being also slapped by him. (Ḳ.)
laxabN The trees which produce what is called muqolN, q. v. (Ḳ.)
mulax-abN One who is slapped much, or violently, in altercations. (Ḳ.)
laxotN Great, or big, in body: (Lth, Ṣgh, and some copies of the Ḳ:) or great, or big, and corpulent. (So in the other copies of the Ḳ.)
A woman in whom the division between the vagina and the rectum has been broken through; syn. mufuDaApN. (Ḳ.)
Har-N saxotN laxotN Vehement, or intense, heat. (Lth, Ḳ.) [See also saxotN: and see laHotN.] Thought by ISd to be arabicized. (TA.)

2. lx-Shu, (A, TA,) inf. n. taloxiySN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He explained, expounded, or interpreted, it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) he made it clear; (A, Ḳ;) namely, language: (A:) taloxiySN and taboyiynN and XaroHN and taxoliySN all signify the same: (A:) he went to the utmost point in explaining it, expounding it, interpreting it, and making it plain: namely, a thing; as also lH-Shu. (TA.) You say, lax-iSo liI xabaraka Explain thou to me thy news, or information, thing after thing. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, qaEada litaloxiySi maA Qlotabasa EalaI gayorihi He sat to. (TA.)

He made it near: [the inf. n. being explained in the TA by Altqryb; but I incline to think that this is a mistranscription, for Alt-Eoriybu; and that the meaning is, he made it clear, plain, distinct, or perspicuous:] he abridged it: he restricted, or limited, himself in it, namely, a saying, and abridged of it what was needful. (TA.)
mulax-aSN The sum or result or conclusion [of a thing]. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: lxf / lxm / lxn / lxI
dictScrap.label:
[lxf, lxm, lxn and lxI
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. lad-, originally ladida, (second pers. ladidota, L,) aor. _a {yalodadu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. ladadN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) He was violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb.)

lad-ahu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _a {yalodadu}, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. lad-N, (L, Mṣb,) He overcame him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:*) or he opposed him violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (Mṣb.) ladidota, (in some copies of the Ḳ, ladadota,) inf. n. laddN, (IḲṭṭ, L: in the Ḳ, lad-N:) Thou becamest such as is called Oalad- [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c.]. (IḲṭṭ, L, Ḳ.)

lad-ahu Eani AlOamori, (inf. n. lad-N, L,) He restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him from doing the thing: (L, Ḳ:*) he made him to return or revert, or turned him back or away, with gentleness, from the thing, or affair; like rad-ahu: (T and L, art. rd:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (L.)

lad-ahu, (Ḳ,) or lad-ahu biAll-aduwdi, (M,) aor. _u {yalodudu}, (L,) inf. n. lad-N and luduwdN; (M, Ḳ;) and Ald-hu↓; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and lad-ahu All-aduwda; (M, L, Ḳ;) He administered to him the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (Ṣ,* M, L, Ḳ.*) The action termed All-ad-u is the taking a child's tongue, and drawing it to one side, and pouring medicine in the other side, between the tongue and the side of the mouth. (Fr, L.)
lud-a He had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) See also 8.
ladadotuhumu Aln-aSiyHapa ‡ I administered to them sincere, or faithful, advice, or counsel, like as one administers the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (L.)

entry.sense: 2. ld-d bihi i. q. nd-d bh, (L, Ḳ,) i. e., He rendered him notorious, or infamous. (L.)
3. lAd-hu, inf. n. lidaAdN (A, Mṣb) and mulaAd-apN, (A,) He contended with him violently, or vehemently, in an altercation; in a dispute; in a litigation. (A, Mṣb.)
maA zilotu OulaAd-u Eanoka I ceased not to repel from thee; or, to defend thee. (Ṣ.)
4. Ald-hu He found him to be such as is called Oalad- [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c.]. (TA.)
Ald- bihi He opposed him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (TA.) See also 1 and 3.
5. tld-d ‡ He turned his face to the right and left, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in confusion, perplexity, or amazement: (L, Ḳ:) from All-adiydaAni signifying “the two sides” of the neck. (Ṣ, L.)
He tarried, or waited, in expectation. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 8. Altd-, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and Altd- laduwdFA, (Ṣ, L,) He swallowed a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd. (Ṣ,* L,* Ḳ.) See also lud-D.
Altd- Eanohu He declined from him, or it. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: lad-N: see laAd-N.
A [sack of the kind called] juwaAliq: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) like labiydN. (TA.)

hom.sense: laduwdN: see laAd-N.

laduwdN and ladiydN↓ A medicine (or draught, Aṣ, L) that is poured into one of the two sides of the mouth (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) by means of the instrument called musoEuT: (L, Ḳ:) pl. Oalid-apN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) from All-adiydaAni signifying “the two sides” of a valley. (Ṣ, L.) It is said in a proverb, jaraI minohu majoraI All-aduwdi [It acted upon him, or affected him, like the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd; i. e., unpleasantly, or disagreeably]. (ISk, Ṣ.) See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 282
ladiydN: see laduwdN.

ladiydaAni The two sides of a valley: (Ṣ, A, L:) each of them is called ladiydN: (L:) and the two sides of the neck, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) below the ears: (L, Ḳ:) or the two lateral muscles of the neck: (M, L:) the two sides of the mouth: (A, L:) and of the penis: (L:) and (as some say, L) of anything: (L, Ḳ:) pl. Oalid-apN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and ladiydN, accord. to AA, signifies the outside of the neck. (L.)
See laAd-N.

entry.sense: laAd-N and laduwdN↓, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter having an intensive sense, and lad-N↓, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore also intensive], (Mṣb,) A man who overcomes in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:*) or, who opposes violently, or vehemently, and very violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Mṣb:) and Oalad-u↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OalanodadN↓ and yalanodadN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) a man violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) or difficult therein, and vehement in war: (IḲṭṭ:) or a contentious, disputatious, or litigious, (L,) and tenacious adversary, who will not incline to the truth: (L, Ḳ:) the fem. of Olad-u↓ is lad-aMCu: (L, Mṣb:) and the pl, lud-N (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and lidaAdN: (L, Ḳ:) the O in OalanodadN↓ and the I in yalanodadN↓ are letters of quasi-coördination, [i. e., added to render those two words quasi-coordinate to safarojalN,] as is shown by the two dáls being not incorporated by idghám; for it is allowable to add a letter at the beginning of a word for the purpose of quasi-coördination when the word has another augmentative letter: (IJ, L:) the dim. of OalnodadN↓ is Oulayod-u↓, because it is originally Oalad-u, the n being added to render it quasi-coördinate to safarojalN. (Ṣ, L.) qawomFA lud-FA in the Ḳur, [xix. 97,] is said to signify A people who are adversaries perverted from the truth: or, who are deaf to the truth. (L.) You say also, huwa XadiydN ladiydN [assimilating the second epithet in form to the first, He is strong, and one who overcomes in contention, &c.] (A.)
Oalad-u and OalanodadN and yalanodadN and Oulayod-u: see laAd-N.
maloduwdN A man who has had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Almutalad-adu ‡ The neck. (A, L, Ḳ.)
maA liI Eanohu mulotad-N I have no way of avoiding, or escaping, it: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) as also muHotad-N. (Ṣ, L.)
1. ladaba: see lacaba.
3. laAdaba: see lacaba.

dictScrap.title: lds / ldg / ldm / ldn
dictScrap.label:
[lds, ldg, ldm and ldn
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: lac-ahu, (M, L, Ḳ,) first pers. lacicotu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yalac-u, (T, M, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. lac-N (M, L) and lac-apN (Mṣb) and lacaAcN and lacaAcapN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) He found it laciyc [i. e. pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; he delighted in it; he took pleasure, or delight, in it]; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also lac-a bihi, and Altc-hu↓, and Altc-↓ bihi, and Astlc-hu↓: (M, Ḳ:) or he counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, it pleasant, &c.; (L;) as also lac-a bh, and Altc-hu↓, and Altd-↓ bh, (A, L,) and Astlc-hu↓: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) lacicotu AlX-aIoCa and lacicotu bh and Uisotalocacotuhu are syn.; (En-Naḍr, T, L;) and so are Uilotacacotu↓ bh and talac-acotu↓ bh. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)
caA mim-aA yaluc-uniI, and yulac-icuniI↓, [and yulic-uniI, (see an ex. of its act. part. n. voce muric-N, in art. rc,) This is of the things that please, or delight, me]. (A.)
2: see 1.

3. lAc- Alr-ajulu QmoraOatahu, inf. n. mulaAc-apN and licaAcN, [The man gave pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment, to his wife, receiving the same from her,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 6.
4: see 1.
5. talac-acotu [I became pleased, or delighted; or I pleased, or delighted, myself]. (A.)
See also 1.
6. talaAc-aA [They (a husband and his wife) gave each other pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 3.
8: see 1.
[Astlc- also signifies He experienced pleasure, or delight.]
lac-N Sleep. (IAạr, T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
See also lac-apN and laciydN.

lac-apN Pleasure; delight; contr. of OalamN; (M, L, Ḳ;) so explained because it happens not save to one who is of sound constitution, free from pains; syn. with XahowapN [in one of the senses of this latter word], or nearly so: (TA:) pleasantness; delightfulness; deliciousness; lusciousness, sweetness: (the Lexicons passim: see the intrans. v. lac-a, of which it is an inf. n.) pl. lac-aAtN. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

lacowaI↓, of the measure faEolaI, also signifies the same as lac-apN, and is formed by the change of one of the two dháls into w; [in the L I;] a change similar to that in taqaD-aI. (L.) It occurs in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, relating to the present world, qado maDaI lacowaAhaA wabaqiIa balowaAhaA [Its pleasure, or delight, or pleasantness, or delightfulness, hath passed away, and its probation remaineth]. (L.)
Also lac-apN and lacaAcapN↓ and laciycN↓ and lacowaI↓ The eating and drinking in a state of ease, comfort, or pleasure, and competence. (IAạr, T, L.)
See laciycN.

laciycN and lac-N↓ are used in the same manner, as epithets, (Lth, T, L,) from the intrans. v. lac-a, (L,) signifying Pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; (the Lexicons passim;) desirable, or desired: (L:) pl. of both, licaAcN; and of the latter, [or of both,] luc-N. (M, Ḳ.)

XaraAbN laciycN, and lac-N↓, (Ṣ, M, L,) and kaOosN lac-apN, (M, L,) and XaIoCN laciycN, and lac-N↓, (A,) [A pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury, beverage, or wine, and cup of beverage, or wine, and thing].
[You say] lahu EayoXN lac-N↓ [He has a pleasant, or delightful, life]: and huwa fiI lac-K↓ mino EayoXK [He is in a pleasant, or delightful, state of life]. (A.)
rajulN lac-N↓ A man of pleasant, or delightful, conversation, or discourse. (A.)
A man in the enjoyment of pleasure, or delight: (M, L:) and Oalic-apN [pl. of lac-N] Those who take their pleasures, or delights. (Ḳ.)
All-aciycu and All-ac-apu↓ Wine: pl. luc-N and licaAcN. (Ḳ.)
See lac-apN.
lacaAcapN: see lac-apN, and 1.
lacowaI: see lac-apN.
caA OaToyabu waOalac-u [This is more. or most. pleasant and delightful,, &c.] (A.)

malac-N A place of lac-ap [i. e. pleasure, or delight]: pl. malaAc-u. It is said in a trad. UicaA rakiba OaHadukumu Ald-aAb-apa faloyaHomilohaA EalaI malaAc-ihaA [When any one of you rides the beast of carriage, let him urge it to run upon the places that are pleasant to it]; i. e. let him make it run upon plain, or even, not rugged, ground, (L.)

Aall-aco and Aall-aci [thus written with two láms] dial. forms of Al-aciI: dual All-acaA, with the n elided: pl. Al-aciyna; and sometimes, in the nom. case, Al-acuwna. (Ṣ.) Their proper art. is lcI. (IB, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce tazab-aI.]

1. lacaba, aor. _u {yalocubu}, inf. n. lucuwbN; and laAcaba↓; He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (Ḳ:) or correctly written with d, unpointed: but IDrd doubts whether correctly with c or with d. (TA.) See also lazaba.
3: see 1.

dictScrap.title: lcE / lcm / lcI
dictScrap.label:
[lcE, lcm and lcI
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. laz-a AlX-aIoCu biAlX-aIoCi, (TḲ,) [aor., app. _i,] or laz-ahu, aor. _u {yalozuzu}, (so in a copy of the Mṣb,) inf. n. laz-N, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) The thing clave to the thing: (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TḲ:) it stuck, or adhered, to it. (TA.) See also 8.
[Hence,] lazazota biI yaA fulaAnu ‡ [Thou hast importuned me, or wearied me by thine importunity, O such a one]. (A.)

laz-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yalozuzu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. laz-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and lazazN, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or lazaAzN, (L, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) He fastened it, or made it fast; or he bound it, or tied it; syn. Xad-ahu: and he stuck it, or made it to adhere; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Alz-hu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UilozaAzN. (TA. [But it is afterwards said in the TA, that, accord. to the TṢ, Oalozazotu bihi in the sense of OaloSaqotu bihi was disallowed by Aṣ.]) You say also, laz-ahu bihi, (TḲ,) inf. n. laz-N, (Ḳ,) He made it to cleave to it; (Ḳ,* TḲ;) like the lizaAz of a house or chamber. (Lth, TA.) And luz-aA They (two camels) were tied together: and they (the two shanks of a camel) were straitly connected in the shackles. (TA.)
He fastened it, namely a door, with a lizaAz, or bar; he barred it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
He thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)
laz-ahu UilaI kacaA ‡ He necessitated him, or constrained him, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. laz-azahu He (God) caused him to be compact and strong in make. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
3. laA zazotuhu, (inf. n. lizaAzN, TA,) I associated with him; became his companion. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)
4. Alz-hu: see 1.
8. Altz- bihi It became coupled with it, and stuck to it. (A.) See also 1.
rajulN kaz-N laz-N A niggardly, tenacious, man: (AZ, TA:) or the latter epithet is an imitative sequent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
laz-u Xar-K: see lizaAzu Xar-K.
liz-N Xar-K: see lizaAzu Xar-K.

hom.sense: lazazN: see lizaAzN.
Straitness, difficulty, distress; or the like; syn. Xid-apN. (TA.)
A state of crowding together of people in a narrow compass. (Mṣb.)
EayoXN lazazN A strait, or difficult, life (Mṣb.)

lizaAzN A piece of wood with which a door is fastened; the bar of a door; (A,* Ḳ,* TA;) as also lazazN↓. (Ḳ.) [Said in the Ṣ, where it is not explained, to be from lizaAzu xaSomK, q. v. infra.; but accord. to the A, it is proper, not tropical.]

huwa lizaAzu maAlK ‡ He is one who [by close and constant attention] takes good care of camels, or other property. (A, TA.) [Hence,] jaEalotuka lizaAzFA lifulaAnK ‡ I have made or appointed thee [to be a manager of such a one;] not to suffer such a one to disobey or oppose. (A,* TA.)
huwa lizaAzu xaSomK ‡ [He is one who cleaves to an adversary in contention or litigation]. (Ṣ, A.)
Uin-ahu lizaAzu xuSuwmapK ‡ Verily he is pertinacious in contention or litigation; commissioned and able to manage it. (TA.)
fulaAnN lizaAzu Xar-K, (TA,) and laziyzu↓ Xar-K, and liz-u↓ Xar-K, (Ḳ,) and laz-u Xar-K, (TA,) ‡ Such a one is one who pertinaciously adheres to evil or mischief. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: lazuwzN an imitative sequent to EajuwzN. (Ḳ.)
laziyzu Xar-K: see lizaAzN.
milaz-N, applied to a man, and in like manner, without p, to a woman, ‡ Vehement, or pertinacious, in adhering. (TA.)
Vehement in contention or litigation; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) pertinacious in adhering to that which he desires, or seeks, to obtain. (Ṣ.)
mulaz-azN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or mulaz-azu Alxaloqi, (A,) A man (A, TA) compact and strong in make; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) having a well-knit frame. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. lazaO and AlzO↓, (Ḳ,) or the former only, (TA,) He filled (Ḳ) a water-skin or the like. (TA.)
lazaOahu, aor. _a {yalozaOu}; and lz-Oh↓, (Ḳ,) and AlzOh↓; (TA;) He gave him [a thing]. (Ḳ, TA.) In the Ḳ, this portion is confused, as well as defective. (TA.)
lazaOato She (a woman) brought forth. (Ḳ.) [You say] qabaHa Qll-ehu Oum-FA lazaOatohu, (TA,) or lazaOato bihi (Ṣ,) [May God remove far from good, or prosperity, the mother that brought him forth!]
lazaOa; (Ḳ;) and lz-O↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taloziYapN; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) He tended camels well. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. AlzO He satiated sheep, &c. (Ḳ) with pasture. (TA.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 5. tlz-O riy-FA It, or he, was, or became, filled to saturation, or satiety. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. lazaba, aor. _u {yalozubu}, inf. n. luzuwbN, It was, or remained, fixed, settled, firm, or constant. (Ḳ.)
lazaba, aor. and inf. n. as above, It (mud, &c., Ṣ) adhered, clave, or stuck. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
lazuba, aor. _u {yalozubu}, inf. n. lazobN and luzuwbN, [It became commixed, or commingled: it intermixed; or it became contracted;] one part of it entered into another. (Ḳ.)
lazaba and lazuba It (mud) cohered, and became hard. (Ḳ.)
lazaba, aor. and inf. n. as at first, It was a time of drought, of no rain. (Ḳ.)
lazabatohu AlEaqorabu i. q. lasabatohu; The scorpion stung him. (Kr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tlAzb Alt-amoru The dates stuck together. (L, art. nDH.)
lazobN Strait; narrow; difficult. E. g. EayoXN lazobN A strait, or difficult life. (TA.)
lizobN A narrow road, or way. (Ḳ.)

lazabN immediately following EazabN, (in the CK, garabN,) [meaning a man “who has no wife,”] is an imitative sequent [used by way of pleonasm and corroboration]. (Ḳ.) So likewise lazabapN after EazabapN. (Ibn-Buzruj.)
lazibN Little in quantity or number: pl. lizaAbN. (Ḳ.) E. g. maACN lazibN Little water. (TA.)

lazobapN Adversity; difficulty; distress; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) drought: (Ṣ:) pl. lizabN (IJ, Ḳ: in the CK lazobN) and lazobaAtN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter with the z quiescent, because it is [originally] an epithet. (Ṣ.) E. g. OaSaAbatohumo lazobapN Distress and drought befell them. (Ṣ.)
sanapN lazobapN A severe year; a year of drought. (TA.)
laAzibN Adhering, or adhesive, or cohesive, clay or mud. (Ṣ.)
Being, or remaining, fixed, settled, firm, or constant. (Ṣ.)

SaAra AlX-aIoCu Darobapa laAzibK The thing became fixed, settled, firm, or constant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and severe: (TA:) [or, a constant infliction:] or, indispensable, or necessary: i. e., the blow of a sword that sticks, or remains fixed, [in the wound]. (Aboo-Bekr, cited in the TA.) lAzb is here the same as lAzm: (Ḳ:) the latter is the original word; the m being changed into b; and is also used in this phrase: (TA:) but lAzb, in this instance, is the more chaste. (Ṣ.)
En-Nábighah says,
falaA taHosibuwna Alxayora laA Xar-a baEodahu
walaA taHosibuwna AlX-ar-a Darobapa laAzibi
[Then think ye not that good shall have no evil after it, nor think ye that evil shall be a constant infliction]. (Ṣ.) Ṣgh says, of the conversion of riwaAgapN into riyaAgapN, or of w into I because of kesreh before it, hecaA Alqalobu layosa biDarobK laAzibK [This conversion is not a necessary sort.] (TA in art. rwg.)
milozaAbN Very avaricious; tenacious, or niggardly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. malaAziybu. (Ṣ.)

1. lazija, aor. _a {yalozaju}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. lazajN and luzuwjapN (M) and luzuwjN; (Mṣb;) and tlz-j↓; (M;) It (a thing, Ṣ) stretched out, in a neut. sense: it roped; or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts: syn. tamaT-aTa and tamad-ada: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, so as to adhere to the hand and the like. (Mṣb.)
lazija bihi It adhered to him, or it, as glue or the like; syn. gariIa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) E. g. Oakalotu XayoYFA falazija biOaSaAbiEiI I ate a thing and it adhered to my fingers. (Mṣb.)
[And] tlz-j↓ It (food, or ointment,) became [viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, slimy, ropy, or mucilaginous,] like xiTomiI- [or marsh-mallow]. (M, &c.)

tlz-j↓ Aln-abaAtu i. q. talaj-ana: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e., The herbage became flaccid, and one part thereof inclined over another: (TA:) [or became flaccid, and of a viscous consistency, or viscous or mucilaginous in its juice; as appears from what here follows]. Ru-beh says, [in the Ṣ, El-ʼAjjáj,] describing a pair af asses, male and female,
wafaraEaA mino raEoIi maA talaz-ajaA
[And they finished pasturing upon what had become flaccid, and of a viscous consistency]. For, says J, [immediately after citing these words of the poet,] when herbage begins to dry up, its juice thickens, and becomes like the mucilage of the xiTomiI- [or marsh-mallow]. (TA.) Or the words of the poet, above quoted, signify, And they finished pasturing upon what they had searched after constantly, or time after time: for talaz-ujN also signifies the searching of a beast of carriage after herbage and leguminous plants, constantly, or time after time: and the two asses are here the agents of the verb tlz-jA. (L.)
5: See 1.
tlz-j raOosuhu His head remained unpurified of its dirt (Ṣ, Ḳ) after he had washed it. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.)

lazijN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and mutalaz-ijN↓ (M), A thing stretching out, in a neut. sense: roping; or drawing out, with a viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, or slimy, continuity of parts: syn. mutamaT-iTN and mutamad-idN: (Ṣ:) viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, so as to adhere to the hand or the like: (Mṣb:) balogamN lazijN [Viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, or ropy, phlegm]. (TA.) zabiybapN lazijapN A sticky raisin. (L.)
rajulN lazojapN, and lazijapN, and laziyjapN, A man who keeps to his place, and does not quit it. (Ḳ.)
mutalaz-ijN: see lazijN.

dictScrap.title: lzq / lzm / lzn
dictScrap.label:
[lzq, lzm and lzn
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: laAzawardN [and laAzuwarodN], an arabicized word, [from the Persian laACowrodo,] A well-known stone; [lapis lazuli;] used as a material with which to write, and as a medicine. (MF.)
[laAzawarodiI-N and laAzuwarodiI-N Of the colour of lapis lazuli.]

hom.sense: 1. lasabahu, aor. _i {yalosibu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and _a, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lasobN, (Ṣ,) It (a scorpion, Ṣ, or a serpent or other thing, Ḳ, as a scorpion, and wasp, but generally said of a scorpion, TA,) stung him, or bit him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
lasabahu OasowaATFA He flogged him with whips. (Ṣ.) lasabahu biAls-awoTi He flogged him with the whip. (Ḳ.)
lasiba, aor. _a {yalosabu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. lasobN, (Ṣ,) He licked honey, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the like, (Ḳ,) as clarified butter. (TA.)
lasiba bihi, aor. _a {yalosabu}, It adhered, clave, or stuck, to it, or in it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like laSiba. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: lasobapN, like laEoqapN, A single lick of honey or the like. (TA.)
maA taraka lasuwbFA, and las-uwbFA↓, He left not anything: [lit., what might be licked off]. (Ḳ.) [See also kasuwbN.]
las-uwbFA: see lasuwbFA.

1. lasada, aor. _i {yalosidu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and _u, (M,) inf. n. lasodN; (Ṣ;) and lasida, aor. _a {yalosadu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. lasadN; (Ṣ;) the latter mentioned by AḤát, (Ṣ,) or Aboo-Khálid, (L,) in the Kitáb el-Abwáb, (Ṣ, L,) but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) It (a lamb or kid, Ḳ, or the young one of a clovenhoofed animal, Ṣ, M,) sucked its mother: (Ṣ, M, L:) or sucked her so as to exhaust all that was in the udder. (M, L, Ḳ.)
Also, both verbs, He (a dog) licked a vessel: (M, Ḳ:) or he (a man) licked what was in the vessel. (IḲṭṭ.)
Also, the former, He licked honey: (Ṣ:) and anything. (M.) You say lasadati AlwaHoXiy-apu waladahaA The female wild animal licked her young one. (M.)
milosadN A young camel that sucks: (L:) or that sucks much. (Ḳ.)

dictScrap.title: lsE / lsm / lsn
dictScrap.label:
[lsE, lsm and lsn
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. laS-a, aor. _i {yaloSiSu}, He thieved, or stole: (A:) [see luSuwSiy-apN, and the other nouns mentioned therewith, some of which, if not all, are app. inf. ns. of this verb:] and tlS-S↓ signifies the same; or he was thievish: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) [or he practised theft:] or he thieved, or stole, repeatedly: (A, TA:) and he acted as a spy; syn. tajas-asa. (TA.)
laS-a AlX-aIoCa,, aor. _u {yaloSuSu}, (Mṣb, TḲ,) inf. n. laS-N, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in the CK liS-N,] He stole the thing: (Mṣb:) [and] he did the thing secretly, or covertly. (A, Ḳ.)
laS-a baAbahu, (TA,) inf. n. laS-N, (A, Ḳ,) He closed, or locked, his door; syn. Oagolaqahu and OaTobaqahu; (A, Ḳ, TA;) as also raS-ahu. (TA.)

laS-a, [app. in the sec. pers. laSiSota, and aor. yalaS-u, and inf. n. laSaSN,] His teeth (OaDoraAs) were near together, so that no interstice was seen between them. (M, TA.) [This verb probably has all the significations indicated by the explanations of laSaSN below.]

entry.sense: 2. lS-S bunoyaAnahu, (M,) inf. n. taloSiySN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made his building firm and compact; or firm and strong; i. q. raS-aSahu; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) of which it is a dial. form. (Ṣ.)
5. talaS-a see 1.
8. AltS- It stuck, or adhered, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) bihi to him. (TḲ.)

liS-N (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and luS-N↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by Aṣ, (Mṣb,) but only the former known to Sb, (M,) and laS-N, (IDrd, A, Ḳ,) A thief; a robber; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also laSotN, with t substituted for the [second] S, and the form of the word changed because of the substitution, or it is a dial. form of liS-N, and is said by Lḥ to be of the dial. of Teiyi and of some of the Ansár, and also pronounced liSotN, (M,) and luSotN: (Ḳ, art. lSt:) fem. liS-apN, (M,) or laS-apN: (A, Ḳ:) pl. of liS-N and luS-N (IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and laS-N, (IDrd, Ḳ,) luSuwSN, (IDrd, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the first, liSaSapN, (IDrd, TA,) and of the first (M, TA) and second, (M,) liSaASN, (M, TA,) or OaloSaASN: (Ḳ) [and in the TA said to be so in the T: but this is probably a mistake for liSaASN: for ISd says,] the word has no pl. of pauc.: (M:)
and malaS-apN is a quasi-pl. n.: (IJ, M:) the pl. of liS-apN, (M,) or laS-apN, (Ḳ,) is liS-aAtN, (M,) and laS-aAtN, (Ḳ,) and laSaAYiSu, (M, Ḳ,) which last is extr. [with respect to rule]: (M:) and the pl. of liSotN is luSuwtN. (M.)
laS-N and luS-N: see liS-N.

hom.sense: laSaSN Nearness together of the OaDoraAs [or teeth, or molar teeth, or all the teeth except the central incisors,] (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) so that no interstice is seen between them; (M;) as also raSaSN. (M, art. rS.)

And Nearness together of two legs of a quadruped, and of the two thighs: and nearness together of the upper parts of the two knees: (M:) or nearness together of the two shoulder-joints, (Ḳ,) or of the upper parts thereof, so that they nearly touch the ears: (M:) or nearness together of the two shoulder-blades: (M:) and a contraction of the elbows of the horse towards his [breast, or that part of it which is called the] zawor; (Ḳ;) and their cleaving to that part; which is a quality approved in a horse. (TA.)
Also, Nearness of the forehead to the eyebrow. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
See also luSuwSiy-apN.

entry.sense: laSaASN: see what next follows.
luSuwSN: see what next follows.
luSuwSapN: see what next follows.

luSuwSiy-apN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ [in the CK without teshdeed]) and laSuwSiy-apN, (Ks, Ṣ, M, and in a copy of the Ḳ,) the latter of which is the more chaste, though the other is the regular form, (TA,) and luSuwSapN↓, (M, A, and so in the CK in the place of the form next preceding,) or laSuwSapN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA) or luSuwSN↓ and laSuwSN↓, (as in a copy of the Mṣb,) and laSaASN↓ and laSaSN↓, (Ḳ,) Thieving; or thievishness. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

OalaS-u, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or OalaS-u AlOaDoraAsi, (A,) A man (M, A) whose [teeth called] ADrAs are near together (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) so that no interstice is seen between them: (M:) as also OaraS-u: (M, A, Ḳ, art. rS:) fem. laS-aMCu. (M.)

Also, the masc. (Aṣ, TA) and fem., (Ḳ,) or OalaS-u Alfaxicayoni, (A,) One whose thighs cleave together, there being no space between them. (Aṣ, A,* Ḳ.) [See also OaraS-u.] Hence, (TA,) the Zenjee is said to be OalaS-u AlOaloyatayoni, (Ḳ,) i. e. Having the buttocks cleaving together. (TA.) And OalaS-u, (Ṣ,) or OalaS-u Almanokibayoni, (A,) Having the two shoulderjoints near together, almost touching the ears. (Ṣ, A.)
Also the fem., applied to a woman, Impervia coëunti; (M;) as also raS-aMCu. (M, art. rS.)
And, applied to a forehead (jabohap), Narrow. (Ḳ.)
And, applied to a sheep or goat, Having one of her horns extending forwards and the other backwards. (Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
malaS-apN quasi-pl. n. of liS-N. (IJ, M.)
OaroDN malaS-apN A land in which are thieves, or robbers: (Ṣ, M:) or in which are many thieves or robbers. (Ḳ.)
galaqN maloSuwSN [A closed lock]. (TA.)

1. laSiba Als-ayofu fiI Algimodi, aor. _a {yaloSabu}, (inf. n. laSobN, as in a copy of the Ṣ, perhaps a mistake for laSabN,) The sword stuck in the scabbard, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and would not come forth. (Ṣ.) See also lasiba and lazaba.
laSiba Aljilodu biAll-aHomi (Ḳ) or simply lSb Aljld, (Ṣ,) The skin stuck to the flesh, by reason of emaciation. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
laSiba AlxaAtamu fiI AlUiSobaEi The ring stuck fast upon the finger: contr. of qaliqa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8. AltSb It became narrow. (TA.)

liSobN A small ravine, or gap, (XiEobN SagiyrN,) in a mountain, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) narrower than a lihob, and wider than a XiEob: (Ḳ:) or a cleft (Xaq-N) in a mountain, narrower than a lhb, and wider than a XEb: (Es-Sukkaree:) or the narrow part of a valley: (Ḳ:) and any narrow place in a mountain: (Ṣ:) pl. liSaAbN and luSuwbN. (Ḳ.) [In two copies of the Ṣ, these two pls., app. by the careless omission of the word AljamoEu, are made syn. with liSobN in the last of the senses explained above.]
laSibN Skin sticking to the flesh, by reason of emaciation. (TA.)

A species of [the kind of barley called] sulot, (Ḳ,) difficult to clear [from the husks]: some of it is trodden, and the rest requires [machines, such as are called] manaAjiynu [pl. of manojanuwnN]. (TA.)
Avaricious, tenacious or niggardly, and of difficult disposition. (Ḳ.)
fulaAnN laHizN laSibN Such a one [is a niggard, who] hardly gives anything. (Ṣ)
lawaASibu [pl.], (in the poetry of Kutheiyir, Ṣ,) Narrow and deep wells. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
miloSaAbN A sword that sticks much in the scabbard; (Ḳ;) scarcely coming out from it. (TA.)
mulotaSibN A narrow road. (Ḳ)
laSotN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and liSotN and luSotN (Ḳ) i. q. liS-N, A thief; a robber: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in the dial. of the tribe of Teiyi, (Fr, Ṣ,) who say, for TaS-N, TaSotN: (Ṣ:) pl. luSuwtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See art. lS.

dictScrap.title: lSf / lSq / lT
dictScrap.label:
[lSf, lSq and lT
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. laTaOa biAlOaroDi, aor. _a {yaloTaOu}, inf. n. laToCN; and laTiYa, aor. _a {yaloTaOu}, inf. n. luTuwoCN; He clave to the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Also, the former, without C: UiloTaho occurs in a trad. for UiloTaOo [imper. of laTiYa] Cleave to the ground. (TA.)
laTiYa lisaAniI My tongue became stiff, so that I could not move it to speak. From a trad. (TA.)
laTaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. laToCN, (TA,) He beat a person with a staff or stick: or he beat on the back only. (Ḳ.)
laTaON The wolf: [because it crouches, or crawls, upon the ground]. (TA.)
A hunter, or sportsman: [for the same reason]. (TA.)
raOayotu Alc-iYoba laATiYFA lils-ariqapi [I saw the wolf crouching to steal]. (TA.)
laATiYapN A wound on the head, such as is termed simoHaAqN: (Ḳ:) also termed miloTaON↓ and miloTaOapN↓ [q. v. infra]. (TA.)

Also, A pustule (Ḳ) that comes forth upon a man, scarcely curable; (TA;) said to be from the sting, or bite, of the vuToOap. So in the L; but in the Ḳ, incorrectly, or it is from the sting, or bite, of the vTAp. (TA.)
Also, A small kind of qalanosuwap, that cleaves to the head. (A, TA.)
miloTaON and miloTaOap: see laATiYapN, and also arts. lTI and lT.
The former is also explained as signifying The pericranium itself; a thin cuticle, or membrane, between the bone of the scull and its flesh: accord. to IAth and the L. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. laTavahu, (aor. _i {yaloTivu}, inf. n. laTovN, L,) He struck him with the flat of the hand; or, with a broad piece of wood: (IAạr, Ḳ:) he slapped him with his open hand; syn. Sak-ahu; (Ḳ;) like laTamahu. (TA.) [See also laTasahu.]
laTavahu biHajarK He threw a stone at him; (Ḳ;) as also laTasahu. (TA.)
laTavahu He collected it together. (Ḳ.)
laTavahu AlOamoru, (aor. _i {yaloTivu}, inf. n. laTovN,) The affair was difficult, or troublesome, to him. (Ḳ.)
laTavahu, aor. _i {yaloTivu}, inf. n. laTovN, It (a load, or an affair,) was heavy or burdensome, and hard, or grievous to him. (L.)
laTavN, [aor. _u {yaloTuvu},] inf. n. laTovN, It became corrupt. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. talaATava Almawoju The waves dashed together, or against each other. (Ḳ)
tlATt Alqawomu The people struck each other with their hands: (Ḳ:) or, with swords. (TA.)
malaATitu Places that are struck (tuloTavu) by a load, or burden, or by beating: (Ḳ:) a quasi-pl. n., or a pl. without a sing., or having a pl. respecting which the lexicologists do not agree. (MF.)
mulaATivN Collecting; or a collector; syn. jaAmiEN: (Ḳ:) selling; or a seller; or buying; or a buyer; syn. baAYiEN. (AA.)

1. laTaHahu, aor. _a {yaloTaHu}, (inf. n. laToHN, Ṣ,) He struck him with the palm of his hand; (Ḳ;) as also laTaxahu: or he struck him, not violently, with his open hand: (TA:) or he struck him, not violently, with the palm of his hand and the like: (T:) or he struck him gently on the back (Ṣ, Ḳ) with the palm of the hand; like HaTaOahu. (Ṣ.)
laTaHa bihi He threw him, or cast him, upon the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
laToHN A soil, or pollution, or taint, (like laToxN,) of which, when it is rubbed, there remains no sign. (T, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. laTaxahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaloTaxu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. laToxN, (Ṣ,) He defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, sullied, smeared, besmeared, daubed, bedaubed, bespattered, [rubbed over, or overspread,] sprinkled or splashed, him, or it, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as a garment, (Mṣb,) bidadaA with such a thing, (Ṣ,) as with ink. (Mṣb.) [See also 2.]

laTaxahu biXar-K, (L,) or bisuwoCK, (Mṣb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, He sullied, or bespattered, him with evil [by charging him therewith]: (L:) he [aspersed him; or] charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with evil. (Mṣb.) laTaxahu biOamorK qabiyHK He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (L, arts. lTx and Tyx.)
luTixa biXar-K, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a verb like EuniIa, [pass. in form but neut. in signification,] (Ḳ) He became [aspersed, or] charged, reproached, or upbraided, with evil. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See art. lTH.

entry.sense: 2. lT-xhu He defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, smeared, besmeared, daubed, bedaubed, bespattered, [rubbed over, or overspread,] or splashed, him or it, much. (Mṣb.) [See also 1.]
He daubed him over with perfume, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. Dmx, &c.)

5. tlT-x He, or it, (as a garment, Mṣb,) became defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, besmeared, bedaubed, or bespattered; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [or became so much; or he defiled,, &c., himself; or did so much;] bikacaA with such a thing, (Ṣ,) as with ink. (Mṣb.)

tlT-x biqabiyHK, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, art. Tyx, &c.) and mino qabiyHK, (L,) i. e. [He became charged, reproached, or upbraided, with] something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (L, arts. lTx and Tyx.) tlT-x biXar-K He did evil [and thus defiled himself; he defiled himself by doing evil]. (L.)
laToxN [and laToxapN↓] A small portion or quantity; a particle; of clouds (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and the like, (Ḳ,) and of news, or tidings, or information: (L:) and [a small quantity] of rain. (Ḳ in art. cyl.)
laToxN [A soil, or pollution, or taint]. (See laToHN.)
[And laToxapN↓ A soil, a splash.]
laTixN A man (L) dirty (L, Ḳ) in eating. (Ḳ.)
Anything defiled, dirtied, or besmeared, with something of a different colour. (L.)
laToxapN see laToxN.
luTaxapN and liT-iyxN↓ A stupid man; one of little sense; (Ḳ;) in whom is no good: (TA:) pl. of the former luTaxaAtN. (Ḳ.)
laTuwxN A thing with which another thing is defiled, polluted, dirtied, or besmeared, (Ḳ,) and with which its colour is changed. (TA.)
luTaAxapN What remains of a soil, or pollution, or the like. (L.)
liT-iyxN: see luTaxapN.

dictScrap.title: lTE / lTf / lTm / lTI
dictScrap.label:
[lTE, lTf, lTm and lTI
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. laZ-a: see 4.
[The inf. n.] laZ-N is also syn. with TarodN [The act of driving away;, &c.]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
3. mulaAZ-apN, inf. n. of laAZ-a: and, as also liZaAZN, irregularly, of talaAZ-uwA: see 4, and 6.

4. AlZ- bihi, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) inf. n. UiloZaAZN, (T, Ṣ,) He kept, or clave, or adhered, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) to him, (AZ, T, Ṣ,) not quitting him, (T,) and to it: (T, Ṣ, M:) he applied himself to it perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly; (AʼObeyd,* Ṣ,* M, TA;) as also AlZ- Ealayohi: (M:) and laZ-a↓ bihi, (IDrd, M, TA,) [aor., accord. to general rule, _i,] inf. n. laZ-N and laZiyZN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or the latter is a subst. from AlZ- bh; (M, TA;) in the former sense, (Ḳ,) and in the latter. (M, Ḳ.) You say, AlZ- biAlkalimapi He kept to the expression. (M.) And hence, OaliZ-uwA fiI Ald-uEaMCi biyaA caA AljalaAli waAlUikoraAmi Keep ye in prayer to [the expression] yA cl AljlAl wAlAkrAm; (Ṣ, M,* TA;*) and repeat it often: (TA:) a saying of Ibn-Mesʼood. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence also, (Ṣ, M,) AlmulaAZ-apu↓ fiI AlHarobi (Lth, T, Ṣ, M) The keeping, or applying oneself, perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, to fighting. (M, TA.)
He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in it, namely a place; (Ṣ;) as also AlZ- Elyh. (TA.)
AlZ- AlmaTaru The rain continued, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) and was incessant. (M.)

6. talaAZ-uwA, inf. n., irregularly, mulaAZ-apN↓ and liZaAZN, They kept, or applied themselves, perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, to fighting, one with another. (M.) talaAZ-N is also syn. with taTaArdN: (Ḳ, TA:) you say, mar-ati AlfurosaAnu talaAZ-u [The horsemen passed by charging upon, assaulting, or attacking, and fighting, one another]. (TA.)

laZ-N, (Ḳ,) or laZ-N kaZ-N, (T, Ṣ, M,) A man hard, or difficult, in disposition; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also laZolaAZN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) or a man hard, o difficult, in disposition, (T, M;) and treated with severity, or rigour, (T,) or straitened; (M;) as also milaZ-N↓ and miloZaAZN↓: (M:) kZ- is app. an imitative sequent. (M.) You say, Uin-ahu laHadiydN laZolaAZN↓ Verily he is [sharp and] evil (zaEir) in disposition. (TA.)
laZolaAZN: see laZ-N, in two places.
It also signifies Chaste in speech; or eloquent. (TA.)
And sometimes, (Fr,) A hot day. (Fr, Ḳ.)
muliZ-N Keeping, cleaving, or adhering; (T;) not quitting. (T, Ṣ.) You say, huwa muliZ-N bihi He is keeping, cleaving, or adhering, to him; (T;) not quitting him. (Ṣ, T.)

A man much attached, addicted, or given, to a thing; (T;) who applies himself perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, (T, Ṣ,) to it; as also miloZaAZN↓: (T:) or the latter signifies very persevering, assiduous, or constant. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
milaZ-N Keeping, cleaving, or adhering, fast: applied to a creditor. (TA.)
See also laZ-N.
miloZaAZN: see muliZ-N, and laZ-N.
laZaON A little (and mean, or contemptible, TA) thing; a little. (Ḳ.)

dictScrap.label:
[lZI
See Supplement.]

hom.sense:
1. laEiba, aor. _a {yaloEabu}, inf. n. laEibN (which is the original [and most common] form, TA) and liEobN (Ṣ, Ḳ: the latter of these inf. ns. contracted from the former, Mṣb) and laEobN (Ḳ: also contracted from the first: not heard by IḲt; but authorized by Mekkee, and, accord. to him, agreeable with a constant rule, applicable in the case of any word of a similar measure having a guttural letter as its medial radical, whether a noun or verb: TA:)
and OuloEuwbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and taloEaAbN; (Ḳ; but this last has an intensive, or a frequentative, signification; Ṣ;) and lE-b↓ (Ḳ) and tlE-b↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ: but this last has a frequentative [or an intensive] signification; Ṣ; [and so too has that immediately preceding it;]) and tlAEb↓; (Ḳ;) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: contr. of jad-a, which signifies “he was serious, or in earnest.” (Ḳ.) [You say] bayonahumo OuloEuwbapN Between them is playing, sporting, or the like. (Ḳ.) [And so] laAEabahaA↓, (inf. n. mulaAEabapN and liEaAbN, TA,) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked, with her: (Ḳ:) [he toyed, dallied, or wantoned, with her:] and laAEabotu Alr-ajula, inf. n. mlAEbp, I played, &c., with the man. (Ṣ)
laEibati Alr-iyHu biAlmanozili, and talaAEabat↓, ‡ [The wind sported with the lighting-place, or place of abode]: i. e., obliterated the traces of it. (TA.)
laEiba binaA Almawoju [The waves sported with us]: the commotion of the waves is called “sporting” because it does not convey the voyagers to the quarter whither they desire to go. (TA, from a trad.)

laEaba, (and laEiba, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaloEabu}, inf. n. laEobN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AlEb↓; (Ḳ;) He (a child, Ṣ) slavered; drivelled; emitted a flow of slaver or drivel from his mouth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The first word is the most approved: (TA:) or AlEb↓ AlS-abiI-u signifies the child became slavering, or drivelling. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. OaloEabahaA He made her to play, sport, or game, &c., (with him: accord. to the CK:) or he brought her a thing with which to play, &c. (Ḳ.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 5. tlE-b He played time after time. (Ṣ.) See 1.
6: see 1.

10. AstlEbt Aln-axolapu The palm-tree produced some unripe dates after its other we had been cut off: (Ḳ:) or produced, or put forth, a spadix or more, having yet upon it some remains of its first produce of fruit. (Aboo-Saʼeed.)
laEobN for EalobN: see the latter.
liEobN: see laEibN

laEibN and liEibN↓ (with two kesrehs, agreeably with a constant rule obtaining in cases of this kind, [whereby the measure faEilN is changed into fiEilN, the medial radical letter being a guttural,] TA, [but in the CK and a MṢ. copy, liEobN↓, which is also regularly changed from the first,]) and OuloEubaAnN↓ and luEabapN↓ (Ḳ) and luEobapN↓ (TA, as from the Ḳ, [but not found by me in any copy of the latter work,]) and tiloEiybapN↓ and tiloEaAbN↓ (Ḳ) and tiloEaAbapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and taloEaAbN↓ and taloEaAbapN↓ and tiliE-aAbN↓ and tiliE-aAbapN↓ (Ḳ: the last like tiliq-aAmapN: the p is added to give [additional] intensiveness to the signification, as in the cases of Eal-aAmapN and nas-aAbapN: it is also used by En-Nábighah El-Jaadee in the place of an inf. n.: TA) and laEuwbN↓ [which is common to both genders] and laE-aAbN↓ (A, &c.) One who plays, sports, games, jests, or jokes, much, or often; a great player, sporter, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
liEibN: see laEibN.

hom.sense: laEobapN (Th, Ṣ) and luEobapN↓ (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) A turn in play, in a game, &c.; a single act of a play or game, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) [You say] limana All-uEobapu↓ [Whose turn is it to play?] with ḍammeh to the l, because it is a subst.; (ISk;) [and] OuqoEudo Oaforuga mino hecihi All-uEobapi↓ [Sit until I finish this turn of the game]: but accord. to Th, it is better to say mn hch All-aEobapi, with fet-ḥah; because what is meant is a single turn in the game. (Ṣ.)
laEibotu laEobapF waAHidapF [I played one game]. (Fr.)
All-aEobapu Albarobariy-apu (in some copies of the Ḳ, All-uEobapu↓) A certain medicine, resembling what is called Als-uwranojaAnu, which fattens. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: luEobapN Anything with which one plays, as XiToranoj and the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and narod. (Ṣ.) See also laEobapN.
A man with whom one plays, sports, or jests: (Ḳ:) one who is a laughing-stock: (TA:) a stupid fellow, or fool, whom one mocks, laughs at, or ridicules; a stupid laughing-stock (Ḳ.)

An image or effigy [with which to play: a puppet: so the word signifies in the present day]. (Ḳ.) [It was probably sometimes applied to A crucifix. And hence, or perhaps from its resemblance to a man with outstretched arms, it is applied by some post-classical writers to A cross; and anything in the form of a cross.]
The image that is seen in the black of the eye when a thing faces it; also called EayorN. (Aboo-Tálib, in L, art. Eyr.)
See laEibN.
liEobapN A mode, or manner, of playing, sporting, gaming, &c. You say, fulaAnN Hasanu All-iEobapi [Such a one has a good manner of playing, &c.] (Ṣ.)
luEabapN: see laEibN.
luEaAbN What flows from the mouth; slaver; drivel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Mucilage of plants. See Ṣ, art. lzj, &c.]
luEaAbu Aln-axoli ‡ The honey of the date-palm. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

luEaAbu AlX-amosi ‡ A thing (that one sees, TA) as though descending from the sky, at the time of the mid-day heat; (Ḳ;) what one sees in a time of intense heat, resembling cobwebs: [i. e. gossamer:] also said to be the saraAb, or mirage: (Ṣ:) it is what is called muxaATu AlX-ayoTaAni, and sahaAmN, and riyqu AlX-amosi, resembling threads, seen in the air when the heat is intense and the air calm: and he who asserts the lEAb AlXms to be the srAb says what is false; for that is the srAb that is seen at mid-day resembling running water: only he knows these things who has been constantly in the deserts, and has journeyed during the mid-day heats. (Az.) [In Egypt, in very hot and calm weather, I have seen, though very rarely, great quantities of the filmy substances above mentioned, resembling delicate and silky white cobwebs, generally of stringy forms, floating in the air.]
jaAriyapN laEuwbN A playful, sportive, or gamesome, damsel: (Ṣ:) one who coquets prettily, with affected coyness: (Ḳ:) pl. laEaAYibu. (TA.) See also laEibN.
laE-aAbN One whose business or occupation is playing, gaming, or the like; a player by profession. (TA.) See also laEibN.
laAEibN Playing, sporting, gaming, jesting, or joking. (TA.) See also laEibN.

laA yaOoxucan-a OaHadukumo mataAEa Oaxiyhi laAEibFA jaAd-FA [By no means shall any one of you take the property of his brother in play (and) in earnest]: by this is meant taking a thing without meaning to steal it, but meaning to vex and anger the owner; so that the taker is in play with respect to theft, but in earnest in annoying. (TA, from a trad.)
Uin-amaA Oanota laAEibN [Thou art only playing]: said to anyone who does what is unprofitable. (TA.)
OuloEuwbapN A thing with which one plays (Mz, 40th nwE.) [See also luEobapN.]
Also an inf. n. of laEiba. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OuloEabaAnN: see laEibN.
maloEabN A place of playing, sporting, gaming, or the like; a place where plays, games, or sports, are performed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. malaAEibu. (TA.)
malaAEibu Alr-iyHi [pl. ‡ The sporting-places of the wind;] places where the wind blows, or has blown, vehemently: syn. madaArijuhaA. (Ḳ.)
tarakotuhu fiI malaAEibi Aljin-i ‡ [I left him in the sporting-places of the Jinn, or genii]: i. e., in such a place that he did not know where he was. (TA.)
muloEibapN and (as in the CK and a MṢ. copy) miloEabapN↓ A garment without sleeves, in which a boy plays. (Ḳ.)
mulaE-ibN [Exuding mucilage]; applied to a plant: likened to a foolish person slavering: (TA, in art. Hmq.) [See Albaqolapu AlHamoqaACu in art. Hmq.]

mulaAEibu Zil-ihi A certain bird; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) found in the desert; (TA;) sometimes called xaATifu Zil-ihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [see art. xTf,] because of the swiftness with which it pounces down: it has a green (or gray, OaxoDar,) back, white belly, long wings, and short neck. (Mṣb.) Of two you say mulaAEibaA Zil-ayohimaA; and of three, mulaAEibaAtu OaZolaAlihin-a; because the appellation becomes determinate. (TA. [But see Zil-N.])
vagorN maloEuwbN Teeth, or fore teeth, &c., having slaver or drivel, upon or about them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dictScrap.title: talEaAbN / tiloEaAbN / taloEaAbapN / tiloEaAbapN / tiloEiybapN / tiliE-aAbN / tiliE-aAbapN

entry.sense: talEaAbN and tiloEaAbN, taloEaAbapN and tiloEaAbapN, tiloEiybapN, tiliE-aAbN and tiliE-aAbapN: see laEibN.
1. laEivN, aor. _a {yaloEavu}, (inf. n. laEavN, TA,) He (a man, TA) was heavy and slow. (Ḳ.)
OaloEavu A man (TA) heavy and slow. (Ḳ)

1. laEaja, aor. _a {yaloEaju}: (inf. n. laEojN, TA) It (a beating, TA) burned the skin: it pained the body: (Ḳ:) it (a beating) pained a person, and burned the skin: (Ṣ:) it (anything burning) pained: it (love, or grief,) burned his heart. (TA.) [See baEaja.] laAEijN is numbered amongst the [few] inf. ns. of the measure faAEilN [like qaAYimN]; and means as explained below. (TA.)
laEaja fI AlS-adori It (an affair) was unsettle in the bosom; syn. xalaxa. (Ḳ.)
3. lAEjhu It (a thing, or an affair,) distressed him. (Ḳ.)
4. AlEx Aln-aAra fiI AlHaTabi He kindled fire in the fire-wood. (Ḳ.)
8. AltEj He burned, or was distressed and disquieted, by reason of grief, or solicitude. (Ḳ.)
laAEijN: see 1.
Ardour of love, or desire, or the like; syn. lawoEapN. (TA.)
Burning or ardent, love: (L:) love that burns the heart. (Ṣ.) [See Hub-N.]
bihi laAEiju AlX-awoqi, and lawaAEijuhu, He suffers the burning pain, and pains, of longing desire. (A.)
mutalaE-ijapN A woman who burns with lust. (Ḳ.)

1. laEisa, aor. _a {yaloEasu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. laEasN, (TA,) [He vas, or became, characterized, by what is termed laEasN and luEosapN; (see the former of these words below;)] he had a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip. (Ḳ.)

laEasN The colour of the lip when it inclines a little to blackness; which is deemed beautiful: (Ṣ:) or a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip (Aṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) and in the gum; (Aṣ, TA;) as also luEosapN↓ [which is likewise syn. with the former word in the other senses here explained]: (A:) or blackness [blending] with redness: and, accord. to El-ʼAjjáj, luEosapN↓ is in the whole of the person: Az says, that laEasN of the complexion is a blackness thereof. (TA.) See also OaloEasu.
luEosapN: see laEasN.

OaloEasu Having a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip: fem. laEosaMCu: pl. luEosN: (Ḳ:) the pl., applied to girls and to women, signifies [as above; or] having a blackness in their lips; (TA;) or having lips of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful: (Ṣ:) the fem. is also applied to a lip, (Xafap,) signifying of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful; (Ṣ;) or having a blackness, deemed beautiful; and in like manner the pl. to lips: (A:) and the masc. to the external skin, (baXar); so applied by El-ʼAjjáj: (TA:) and the fem. to a girl, as signifying having in her complexion the least degree of blackness, and tinged with redness, (A, Ḳ, TA,) not of a clear hue: (TA:) and the pl. to girls, as signifying having a blackness in their complexions. (Az, TA.)
You also say, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes, (Ṣ,) nabaAtN OaloEasu, meaning Abundant and dense herbage; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because such inclines to blackness. (Ṣ.)

dictScrap.title: lET / lEf / lEq / lEm / lEn
dictScrap.label:
[lET, lEf, lEq, lEm and lEn
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. lagaba, aor. _u {yalogubu}, (Ṣ,) and _a (Ḳ); and lagiba, aor _a; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but this latter is of weak authority; (Ṣ;) and laguba, aor. _u {yalogubu}; (Lb, Ḳ;) inf. n. lagobN, (Ḳ,) which is said to be inf. n. of lagaba, aor. _u {yalogubu}, (TA,) and luguwbN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. of lagaba, aor. _u {yalogubu}, and of lagiba, (Ṣ,) and laguwbN, (Ḳ,) which deviates from constant rule, like waDuwCN and qabuwlN, (TA,) and lagabN, which is said to be inf. n. of lagiba, agreeably with analogy; (TA;) He was fatigued, tired, or wearied, (Ṣ, &c.,) in the greatest degree, or to the utmost: (M, Ḳ:) or he was languid in consequence of fatigue: or he was fatigued, tired, or wearied, in spirit, or mind: but most agree, as to the signification, with the Ṣ and Ḳ. (TA.)

lagaAbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ: in the CK, and app. in most MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, expressly said to be lugaAbapN, with ḍammeh:) and luguwbapN (Ḳ) [app. inf. ns., of which the verb is laguba, aor. _u {yalogubu},] The being stupid, and weak: or [if substs.] stupidity, and weakness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

lagaba Ealayohimo, aor. _a {yalogabu}, (inf. n. lagobN, Ṣ,) He spoiled, or marred, their affair, scheme, plot, or the like: syn. Oafosada Ealayohimo: [Oamorahumo, or the like, being understood]. (El-Umawee and Ṣ.)
lagaba Alqawoma He spoke ill, or corruptly, to the people: syn. Had-avahumo HadiyvFA xalofFA. (Ḳ.)
lagaba He (a dog) lapped, or drank by lapping. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. lg-b daAb-atahu He laded his beast with more than it was able to bear. (TA.) See 4 and 5.
