hom.sense: 4. Oalogabahu He fatigued, tired, or wearied him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, and tlg-bhu↓ and lg-bhu↓, It (journeying, or travel,) fatigued, tired, or wearied, him in the greatest degree, or to the utmost. (Ḳ.)
Algb Als-ahoma He made the feathers of the arrow to be what are termed lugaAb. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tlg-b: see 4.
He chased, hunted, or pursued, long: syn. of the inf. n. Tuwlu AlT-arodi. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A poet says,
talag-abaniI dahorN falam-aA galabotuhu
gazaAniI biOawolaAdiI faOadorakaniI Ald-ahoru
[Fortune long pursued me; and when I overcame him, he attacked me with my children; and so fortune overtook me]. (Ṣ.)
tlg-bhu He undertook the management of it, and did it, and was not unequal to it. (TA.)
tlg-b Ald-aAb-apa He found the beast of carriage to be fatigued, tired, or weary; or so in the utmost degree. (TA.) See 2.

lagobN (Ṣ, Ḳ; for which El-Kumeyt has used lagabN↓, like as naharN is used for nahorN, because of the guttural letter; Ṣ) and lugaAbN↓ (Ṣ) and lagiybN↓ (as in the Ṣ and the CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ) or lagibN↓ (as in the TA, from the Ḳ) Bad, disordered, or illcomposed, feathers [of an arrow]: syn. riyXN faAsidN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers (buTonaAn) [when they have not the shorter, or narrower, lateral halves interposed between two of them]: contr. of luWaAmN: (Ṣ:) or the feathers termed lugaAb↓ are the longer [or wider] lateral halves; and a single one of them is called lugaAbapN; [accord. to which explanation, lgAb is a coll. gen. n.;] contr. of lWAm: or the feathers of an arrow, when not equal, even, or uniform, are thus termed; and when equal, even, or uniform, they are termed lWAm: (TA:) lWAm and lgAb are terms applied to two descriptions of feathers; the former, to those whereof a longer [or wider] lateral half is next to a shorter [or narrower] lateral half; and this is the best that can be; and lgAb and lgb are terms applied to those whereof two longer [or wider] lateral halves, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, are next each other. (Aṣ.)

lagobN and lugaAbN↓ An arrow badly trimmed, or shaped; (Ḳ;) badly made: or one of which [all] the wings consist of the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers: or one which has two longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, next each other: or one of which the feathers are incongruous; one in the contr. case being termed luWaAmN: or one that does not go far. (TA.)
riyXa bilagobK [It (an arrow) was feathered with bad feathers].
A surname of a man, brother of Taäbbata-Sharran: (TA:) incorrectly written by J riyXu lagobK. (Ḳ.)
lagobN ‡ Corrupt, or vitious, speech, or discourse; (Ḳ;) not rightly aimed, directed, or disposed; evil, bad, foul. (TA.)
kuf-a Ean-aA lagobaka Turn away from us thine evil, corrupt, or foul, speech. (TA.)
lagobN (like wagobN, TA) and laguwbN↓ ‡ A weak, stupid, man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See an ex. voce kitaAbN.
lagobN The flesh that is between the vanaAyaA, or four front teeth. (Ḳ.)
lagabN: see lagobN.
Oaxaca bilagabi raqabatihi He overtook him. (Ḳ.)
lagibN: see lagobN.
laAgibN and lagobaAnu↓ Fatigued, tired, or wearied; or so in the utmost degree.
saAgibN laAgibN and sagobaAnu lagobaAnu: see art. sgb. (TA, art. sgb.) riyaAHN lawaAgibu ‡ [Languid winds.]. (TA.)
lugaAbN: see lagobN.
lagiybN: see lagobN.
lugaAbapN: see 1.
lugobaAnu: see laAgib.

lagiyvN i. q. galiyvN, (from which it is formed by transposition, TA,) in its two meanings: (Ḳ:) wheat mixed with barley; like bagiyvN: (TA:) [and food mixed with poison, by which vultures are killed].
lug-aAvN [pl. of laAgivN] Sellers of wheat mixed with barley; as also bug-aAvN. (L.)
1. lagada, (aor. _a {yalogadu} T, L, Ḳ, inf. n. lagodN, T, L,) He made camels to turn back to the right way, or road: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or he made camels to keep to the road, or, to the right way. (T, L.)
lagadahu, inf. n. lagodN, He hit, or hurt, his lugoduwd. (IḲṭṭ.)

lugodN and lugoduwdN↓ and ligodiydN↓ A certain portion of flesh in the Haloq [or fauces]: or what resembles redundant portions of flesh within the ear [more fully described below]: or the flesh which surrounds the furthest part of the mouth, towards the Haloq [or fauces]: (Ḳ:) pl. (of lgd, Ṣ) OalogaAdN; and (of lgdwd, Ṣ, and lgdyd, TA) lagaAdiydu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the AlgAd are portions of flesh by the lahaAp; also called lagaAniynu [and lgAdyd]: (AʼObeyd, L:) or the lgAdyd↓ are what resemble redundant portions of flesh within the two ears, inside the mouth; also called the nagaAnig, and the lagaAniyn: (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán:) [see Alfunadobapu:] or the portions of flesh that are between the Hanak [here app. signifying the soft palate] and the side of the neck; as also the AlgAd: (Ṣ:) or outer part of the lgAnyn, which is a name given to the flesh between the nakafataAni and the tongue, internally: (AZ, L:) or the lgd is in the place of the nkftAn, at the root of the neck; also called lgdwd↓ and lgdyd↓: (TA:) or the interior of the naSiyl [or part between the neck and head, beneath the jaw-bone,] between the Hanak [here app. meaning as explained above] and the side of the neck; as also lgdyd↓, and lgdwdAni↓, (JK,) for this description applies to two parts [corresponding each to the other, on the right and left]: (L:) [in the present day it is applied, with apparent correctness, to the gill, or gills, or flesh beneath the lower jaw, of a man or woman, whether in the middle or on either side, and more especially when large:] or the place where ends, at its lower part, the lobe of the ear; (AZ, L, Ḳ;) and also called the nakafap: (AZ, L:) or the AlgAd and lgAdyd↓ are the roots of the two jaw-bones. (L.)
EilojN Daxomu All-agaAdiydi, and AlOalogaAdi, [A sturdy, and big, or coarse, man, large in the gills]. (A.)
sab-aniI Hat-aI OaHomaI lugodahu [He reviled me until he heated his gills; i. e.,] until he became hot (AiHotamaI) by reason of anger. (A.)
lugoduwdN and ligodiydN: see lugodN throughout.
jaMCa mutalag-idFA He came in a state of rage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
1. lagazahu, aor. _u {yaloguzu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. lagozN, (IF, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He turned it from its proper mode or manner; distorted it. (IF, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, TḲ.)

[Hence,] lagaza jiHaratahu, and OalogazahaA↓, He (a jerboa) made his burrows winding, or tortuous, and perplexing to the enterer thereof. And lagaza fiI Haforihi, and Oalogaza↓, He pursued a winding, or tortuous, course in his burrowing. (A.)
2: see 4.
3. raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmizuhu ‡ [I saw him talking enigmatically, or obscurely, with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him.] (A, TA.) [See also 3 in arts. Hjw and EI.]
4: see 1, in two places.

Algz kalaAmahu, (A, Ḳ,) and Algz fiI kalaAmihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) signify alike: (Ḳ:) or the former, ‡ He made his speech, or language, enigmatical, or obscure; not plain: (A:) and the latter, (Ṣ, A,) or both, (Ḳ,) he made his meaning enigmatical, or obscure, in his speech, or language; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also lg-z↓: (A:) or the second, he used parabolical language: (Mṣb:) or both, he concealed a meaning different from that which he made apparent: or he was equivocal, or ambiguous, in his speech, or language, for the purpose of concealment: as in the following verse, cited by Fr:
walam-aA raOayotu Aln-asora Eaz-a Oabona daOuyapa
waEaX-aXa fiI wakorayohi jaAXato lahu nafosiI
‡ [And when I saw that the vulture had overcome the raven, and nested in his nest, (lit., in his two nests,) my soul, or stomach, heaved thereat]: the poet likens hoariness to the vulture, because of its whiteness [or grayness]; and youthfulness to the black raven, because the hair of youth is black. (TA.) You say also, Algz fiI yamiynihi ‡ He practised [equivocation, or ambiguity, (see lug-ayozaI,) or] concealment, [by a mental reservation, or otherwise,] towards the person sworn to, in his oath: the doing of which is forbidden. (A.)
lagozN: see lugazN, throughout.
lugazN: see lugazN, throughout.
lagazN: see lugazN, throughout.

lugazN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and lugozN↓ and lagozN↓ (Ḳ) and lagazN↓ and lugayozaMCu↓ (TA) A winding, or tortuous, excavation or burrow: this is the primary signification: (IAạr, in explanation of lugozN:) the burrow of a jerboa, which he makes between the qaASiEaMC and naAfiqaMC, burrowing strait downwards, and then turning crosswise to the right and left, so that his place becomes concealed: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or the burrow of the [lizard called] Dab-, and of the jerboa, (A, Ḳ,) and of the rat or mouse: (Ḳ:) pl. [of the first four] OalogaAzN. (Ṣ, A.)

Hence, (Ḳ,) OalogaAzN ‡ Winding, or tortuous, roads, or ways, perplexing to him who pursues them. (A,* Ḳ.) You say, Uilozami AljaAd-apa waUiy-aAka waAlOalogaAza ‡ [Keep thou to the main road, and avoid the winding, or tortuous, by-ways, which perplex him who pursues them]. (A, TA.)

Hence also, (Ṣ,) lugazN (Ṣ, A, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ [omitted in the copies of the Ḳ consulted by the author of the TA, through inadvertence, as he observes, but mentioned in the CK,]) and lugozN↓ [which is now the most common form] and luguzN↓ and lagazN↓ (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and lug-ayozaI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with teshdeed to the g, and not a dim., because the I of the dim. does not occupy a fourth place, but like xuD-aAraI and Xuq-aAraI, (Ṣ,) and lugayozaMCu↓, (Az, Ḳ,) like HumayoraMCu, (Ḳ,) [and app. lug-ayozaMCu↓ also, with teshdeed, (see what follows,)] and OuloguwzapN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ An enigma; a riddle; enigmatical, or obscure, language: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or parabolical language: (Mṣb:) pl. (of the first four, Ḳ, TA) OalogaAzN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And in like manner, yamiynN lug-ayozaMCu↓, accord. to Z, with teshdeed to the g mentioned by Sb with xul-ayoTaMCu, or, accord. to Az, without teshdeed, [lugayozaMCu,] which he regards as the dim. of the form with teshdeed, like as sukayotN is of suk-ayotN, ‡ An oath in which is equivocation, or ambiguity, and concealment [by mental reservation or otherwise]. (TA.)
luguzN: see lugazN.
lag-aAzN ‡ One who often, or habitually, speaks evil of others in their absence; (Ḳ, TA;) as though he did so in equivocal or ambiguous language. (TA.)
lugayozaMCu: see lugazN, in three places.
lug-ayozaI and lug-ayozaMCu: see lugazN; the second in two places.
OuloguwzapN: see lugazN.

1. lagaTa, aor. _a {yalogaTu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. lagoTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and lagaTN, (TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and ligaATN; (Ṣ, TA;) and lg-T↓; (Ḳ;) and AlgT↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. AilogaATN; (Ṣ, Mgh;) He spoke clamorously, confusedly, and indistinctly: (Mṣb:) or, said of a number of men, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) they uttered a sound, noise, or cry; and a clamour, confused noise, or mixture of voices or cries: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or they uttered indistinct, and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries. (Mgh, Ḳ.) And lagaTa, aor. _a {yalogaTu}, inf. n. lagoTN and lagiyTN, is said of the pigeon, and of the [bird called] qaTaA, [meaning, It uttered its cry, or cries;] (Ḳ;) or of each of these you say, lagaTa biSawotihi, and AlgT↓. (TA.) [Hence,] Oatayotuhu qabola lagiyTi AlqaTaA, and lagoTihi, [I came to him before the crying of the katà,] meaning, early in the morning. (TA.) [See also laAgiTN.]
2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
AlgT labanahu, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (L,) He threw heated stones into his milk, and so caused it to make the sound termed naXiyX. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: lagoTN: see what next follows.

lagaTN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and lagoTN↓ (Ks, Ḳ) Clamorous, confused, and indistinct, speech: (Mṣb:) or sound, noise, or cry; and clamour, confused noise, or a mixture of voices or cries: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or indistinct and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries: (Mgh, Ḳ:) pl. OalogaATN, (Ḳ,) of the latter as well as of the former. (TA.) You say, samiEotu lagaZa Alqawomi [I heard the clamorous, and confused, and indistinct speech, &c., of the people, or company of men]. (TA.)
laAgiTN [part. n. of 1]. You say, Oatayotuhu qabola AlqaTaA All-aAgiTi [I came to him before the crying katà], meaning, early in the morning: pl. lug-aTN. (TA.) [See also 1.]

hom.sense: 1. lafaOa, aor. _a {yalofaOu}, inf. n. lafoCN and lafaMCN; and AltfO↓; He stripped off, or peeled off, (Ḳ,) meat from a bone. (AZ, Ṣ.)
lafaOati Alr-iyHu Als-aHaAba Eano wajohi Als-amaMCi † [The wind stripped off the clouds from the face of the sky]. (Ṣ.)
lafaOa, inf. n. lafoCN, He peeled a bone (TA) or a stick. (Ṣ.)
lafaOa He beat (Ṣ, Ḳ) with a staff or stick. (Ṣ.)
He turned a person back, or away, from his purpose. (Ḳ.)
lafaOa i. q. UigotaAba; † He traduced a person behind his back, or in his absence, but saying of him what was true. (Ḳ.) Thought to be tropical, from the same verb signifying “he peeled.” (TA.)
lafiYa, aor. _a {yalofaOu}, He, or it remained, or endured. (Ḳ.)

lafaOahu Haq-ahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (like lakaOahu: T:) or lfOh signifies he gave him less than his due. (Ḳ.) Accord. to Aboo-Turab, the verb is used in these two contr. senses. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AlfO He caused to remain, or endure. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
Less than what is just, or right. (Ḳ.)
A little thing; a little. (Ḳ.)
Dust; earth. (Ḳ.)
Small bits of rubbish on the ground. (TA.)

lafiyoYapN A piece of meat stripped off, or peeled off, from a bone: (TA:) a piece of meat in which is no bone: (Ṣ:) pl. lafiIoCN [but this is rather a coll. gen. n., or it is doubtful] and lafaAyaA. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. lafatahu, aor. _i {yalofitu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lafotN, (Ṣ,) He twisted, wrung, or turned, him, or it, (Ṣ, Ḳ), in a way different from his, or its, [proper] direction: as when you grasp a man's throat, and twist or wring it. (TA.)

tilofitu Albaqarapu AlxalaI bilisaAnihaA [The cow turns about the fresh herb with her tongue]. (Ṣ, from a trad.) [For AlxalaA, as in copies of the Ṣ, I have substituted AlxalaI. To this action is likened a hypocrite's reading of the Ḳur-án.]
lafatahu He twisted, or wrung, his neck, and broke it; as also Eafatahu and Hafatahu. (Az, in TA, art. Hft.)
lafatahu Almawotu Death took him away suddenly; as also falatahu. (T, TA, art. flt)
lafatahu, aor. _i {yalofitu}, inf. n. lafotN, He turned him aside, to the right or left. (Mṣb.)
lafatahu Eini AlX-aIoCi aor. _i {yalofitu}, inf. n. lafotN, He turned away, averted, or diverted, him from the thing. (TA.) So in the Ḳur, x., 79. (Fr.)
maA lafataka Eano fulaAnK What hath turned thee away, or averted thee, or diverted thee, from such a one (Fr.)
lafatahu Eano raOoyihi ‡ He turned him from his opinion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
lafata wajohahu Ean-iI He turned away, or averted, his face from me. (Ṣ.)
lafata AlmaAXiyapa, aor. _i {yalofitu}, (inf. n. lafotN, TA,) He beat the camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he struck. (Ḳ.)
lafata AlokalaAma, aor. _i {yalofitu}, inf. n. lafotN, ‡ He sent forth, or uttered, words, without caring what might be the meaning. (TA.)
lafata XayoYFA, [aor. _i {yalofitu},] inf. n. lafotN, He stirred a thing about and over, like as flour is stirred about and over with clarified butter, &c. (TA.) [See lafiytapN.]
lafata All-iHaMCa Eani AlX-ajari He removed, or pulled off, the peel, or rind, from the trees: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to the A, Eani AlEuwdi from the twig, or branch. (TA.)

lafata Alr-iyXa EalaI Als-ahomi He put the feathers upon the arrow not so that they were well-composed, or equal, or even, or uniform, (gayora mutalaAYimK [i. e., not so that they were what is termed luWaAm,]) but as they happened to be. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 8.

8. Altft and tlf-t↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [He looked aside, or about,] the latter of which signifies more than the former, (Ṣ,) are from lafatahu Eano raOoyihi: (Ḳ:) you say, Altft UilaI AlX-aIoCi, and tlf-t↓ Uilayohi, He turned his face towards the thing. (TA.)
[Hence, mA Altft Uilayohi He regarded not him or it; he paid no regard, or attention, to him or it. (The lexicons, &c., passim.)]
Altft biwajohihi yamiynFA waXimaAlFA He turned his face to the right and left. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: lifotN The half of a thing; syn. Xq-N: and its side; syn. SigowN: (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., jaAnibN. (TA.)
laA talotafito lifota fulaAnK Look not towards such a one. (Ṣ.)
A cow, or bull; syn. baqarapN. (Ḳ.)
A woman who is stupid, foolish, or of little sense. (Ḳ.) See also Oalofatu.
The vulva of a lioness. (Ḳ.)

[A name now given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., a edulis; (Delile, Flor. Aeg., No. 597;) the rape;] i. q. salojamN [a name given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., β oleifera: (Delile, ubi supra, No. 598:)] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Az. says, “I have not heard it from any person confided in for accuracy, and know not whether it be Arabic or not:” (TA:) Ibn-El-Kubbee asserts it to be a Nabathean word. (MF.)

entry.sense: lafatN The having one of his horns twisted upon, or over, the other. Said of a he-goat. (Ṣ.)
lufatapN A man who beats (much TA) his camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he strikes. (Ḳ.)
lafaAtN: see Oalofatu.
lafuwtN A woman who looks aside much, or often, at things. (TA.)
A woman who, when she hears a man speak, looks aside towards him. ('Abd-el-Melik Ibn-ʼOmar.)

A woman whose eye does not remain fixed towards one place, the object of whose care is that thou shouldst be heedless of her, and that she may make signs with her eyes, or the like, to another. (Th, Ḳ.)

A woman who has a husband, and who has a child by another husband, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and who therefore turns her regard much towards her child, (Ṣ,) and is occupied by him so as to be diverted from her husband. (TA.)

A she-camel that is unquiet (DajuwrN) on the occasion of her being milked, (Ḳ,) that looks aside at the milker, and bites him; wherefore he strikes her with his hand, and thereupon she yields her milk: this is the case when her young one has died: whence this epithet is proverbially applied to him who is disobedient. (TA.)
Difficult, or stubborn, of disposition. (Ḳ.) But in the Ṣ is said what is at variance with this. (TA.) See lafaAtN, mentioned with Oalofatu,
Accord. to some, A woman in whom is crookedness and contraction; expl. by AltI fyhA AltwAC wAnqbAD. (TA.)
A woman went to calumniate, or slander. (A in art. xft.)

lafiytapN [A certain kind of gruel] made by straining water [or juice, or a decoction,] of the white colocynth, then putting it into a stone cookingpot, and cooking it until it has become thoroughly done and thickened, and then sprinkling flour upon it: (AḤn:) or thickened EaSiydap: (IAth, Ḳ:) or thick ESydp (Ṣ) of habiyd, i. e. HanoZal, [or colocynth]: (TA:) so called because it is stirred about and over liOan-ahaA tulofatu OaIo tulowaI: (Ṣ:) [see lafata XayoYFA:] or broth resembling Hayos: (Ḳ:) i. q. EafiytapN. (TA, art. Eft.) [See also waTiyYap.]
Oalofatu Strong-handed, who hoists, or wrings, him who strives, or grapples, with him. (TA.)
A he-goat having crooked horns. (TA.) lafotaACu A she-goat having crooked horns. (Ḳ.)
A he-goat having one of his horns twisted (Ṣ, Ḳ) upon, or over the other. (Ṣ.)
lafotaACu A woman having distorted eyes; syn. HawolaACu. (Ḳ.)

Oalofatu (in the dial. of Keys, Ṣ) Stupid; foolish; of little sense; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like OaEofatu (Ṣ) [and OaEofaku]: fem. lafotaACu: [see also lifotN:] so too lafaAtN↓: (Ḳ:) or this signifies stupid, foolish, or of little sense, and of difficult, or stubborn disposition: (Ṣ:) [see also lafuwtN:] or, accord. to AʼObeyd, as mentioned in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, lafaAtN↓ and its syn. hafaAtN are correctly written lafaApN and hafaApN, for in a case of pause they are pronounced lafaAho and hafaAho: see hafaAtN. (TA.)
(In the dial. of Temeem, Ṣ,) Left-handed; who works with the left hand; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oalofaku. (TA.)
Almutalaf-itapu The highest bone in the place where the head joins the neck. (L.)
10. Astlfv maA Einodahu He elicited, and exhausted, (UisotanobaTa waQsotaqoSaI,) what [information, &c.] he had, or possessed. (Ḳ.)
Astlfv Alr-iEoIa He consumed the whole of the pasture, leaving nothing of it. (Ḳ, TA.)
Astlfv HaAjatahu He accomplished his want. (Ḳ.)
Astlfv Alxabara He concealed the news. (Ḳ.)
Oalofavu Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (Ḳ:) like Oalofatu. (TA.)
4. Oalofaja and Oulofija He (a man) clave to the ground by reason of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want. (L.)
Alfj, inf. n. UilofaAjN, He, or it, constrained, compelled, or necessitated, a person, to have recourse to one, or to others, not of his family; (Ḳ;) constrained him to beg of such. (L.)
OalofajaniI UilaI celika AlUiDoTiraAru Necessity constrained me to have recourse to that. (AZ.)

Oalofaja, [not Oulofija, as might be thought from the signification of the part. n. mulofajN,] (inf. n. UilofaAjN; Ṣ;) and Astlfj↓; (L:) He became a bankrupt; syn. Oafolasa: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he was, or became, poor: (TA:) he became destitute, possessing nothing. (AʼObeyd.)
10. Astlfj: see 4.
Also, He was, or became, constrained to have recourse to a thing: or was in need. (TA.)
lafojN Abasement; abjectness. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
lufojN The channel of a torrent. (L.)

mulofajN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mulofijN↓ (ISk) and musotalofajN↓ (Ḳ) or musotalofijN (as in the L.) A man in a state of bankruptcy: a bankrupt; syn. mufolisN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former, poor: (ISk:) or a bankrupt and in debt: (IAth:) or destitute; possessing nothing: (AʼObeyd:) the first extr. [with respect to rule], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like muHoSanN from OaHoSana, and musohaba from Oasohaba. (Ṣ.) [See musohabN.]
mulofijN: see mulofajN.

musotalofajN, (as in the Ḳ,) or musotalofijN↓, (as in the L [and this latter I think the correct mode of writing the word in all the senses here explained, for I do not find it noted as extr. with respect to rule like mulofajN,]) [part. n. of 10, q. v.: and] i. q. mulofajN, q. v. (Ḳ.)
One whose heart forsakes him, or fails him, by reason of fear, or fright. (Ḳ.)
Cleaving to the ground by reason of emaciation, (Ḳ,) or of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want; as also mlfj [i. e. mulofijN and mulofajN: see 4]. (TA.)
musotalofijN: see musotalofajN.

1. lafaHatohu Aln-aAru, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yalofaHu}, (M,) inf. n. lafoHN and lafaHaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) The fire smote, or hurt, his face; as also lfHt wajohahu: (M, O:) the fire burned him; (TA;) as also nfHth AlnAr biHar-ihaA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner the hot wind called samuwm: (Ṣ:) lafaHato and nafaHato are syn., except that the effect of Aln-afoH is greater than that of All-afoH: (Zj:) or lafoHN relates to a hot wind; and nafoHN, to a cold, or cool, wind: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) you also say lfHth Als-amuwm meaning the smwm blew in his face. (L.)

Also lafaHahu, aor. _a {yalofaHu}, He smote, or struck, him, with a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) lightly, or slightly: you say lafaHotuhu biAls-ayofi lafoHapF I struck him with the sword a light, or slight, blow. (Ṣ.)
OaSaAbaha lafoHN mino HaruwrK wasamuwmK A burning gust of hot night-wind, and of hot day-wind, smote him. (L.)
OaSaAbahu mina AlHar-i lafoHN wamina Albarodi nafoHN [A blast of heat smote him, and a blast of cold]. (A.)
You say also lawaAfiHu Als-amuwim [pl. of laAfiHapN↓, and meaning Burning blasts of the smwm]. (Ṣ, Ḳ in art. sfE.)
lafoHapN A light, or slight, blow with a sword. (Ṣ.)

luq-aAHN A certain well known plant, (Ḳ,) of the kind termed yaqoTiyniI-N, (L,) which people smell, (Ṣ.) yellow, and of sweet odour, (A, L,) resembling the baAcinojaAn (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) when it becomes yellow; (Ṣ, A;) [accord. to Golius, app. on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, the same which the Syrians and Egyptians call Xam-aAmN, q. v.].

Also, The fruit, or produce, (vamarap,) of the yaboruwH [or mandrake, which is called by this name (ybrwH) in the present day]; (Ḳ;) thus correctly written, with the I before the b [not bbrwH, as in the CK and some MṢ. copies]. (TA.) [It seems that the application of the term lf-AH to both the mandrake and the Xm-Am has led to confusion, and occasioned Linnæus to call the latter “cucumis dudaim.” See also yaboruwHN, and magodN.]
laAfiHapN: see lafoHN.

1. lafaZahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and lafaZa bihi, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yalofiZu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. lafoZN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) and lafiZahu, and lafiZa bihi, aor. _i {yalofiZu}; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) He ejected it; cast it forth; [disgorged it;] (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely a thing that was in his mouth; (T;) his spittle, &c.; (Mṣb;) from (mino) his mouth. (Ṣ, TA.)
And lafaZa alone, [elliptically,] He ejected what had entered between his teeth, of food. (TA.) You say also, lafaZati AlHay-apu sam-ahaA ‡ [The serpent ejected its poison.] (TA.) And lafaZa EaSobahu, lit. He ejected his spittle that stuck and dried in his mouth; meaning ‡ he died; (T, TA;) as also lafaZa nafosahu, aor. _i {yalofiZu}, inf. n. as above; (M, TA;) and lafaZa alone. (M, Ḳ.) And jaMCa waqado lafaZa lijaAmahu, [as to the letter and the meaning like jaMCa waqado dalaqa lijaAmahu,] ‡ He came harassed, or distressed, by thirst and fatigue. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, M, Z, Ḳ.) And lafaZati Alr-aHimu maMCa AlfaHoli ‡ The womb ejected the seminal fluid of the stallion. (TA.) And lafaZahu AlbaHoru † The sea cast it forth upon the shore; (Mṣb, TA;) namely a fish; (TA;) or a beast. (Mṣb.) And lafaZa AlbaHoru bimaA fiyhi UilaI AlX-uTuwTi † The sea cast forth what was within it to the shores. (M.) And qaMCati AlOaroDu OukolahaA walafaZato xabiyoYahaA ‡ The earth disclosed her vegetables, and revealed her hidden things. (TA in this art. and in art. qyO.) And lafaZati AlOaroDu Almay-ita † The earth cast forth the dead; (T, Mṣb;) did not receive, or admit, the dead. (M.) And lafaZati AlbilaAdu OaholahaA ‡ [The countries cast forth their inhabitants]. (TA.)

[Hence,] lafaZa biAlkalaAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and biqawolK, (Mṣb,) and biAlX-aIoCi, (M,) and lafaZa Alqawola, (TA,) aor. _i {yalofiZu}, inf. n. lafoZN, (M,) He uttered, spoke forth, or pronounced, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the saying, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a saying, (Mṣb,) and the thing; (M;) as also tlf-Z↓ bihi. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur, [l. 17,] maA yalofiZu mino qawolK ‡ [He doth not utter a saying]: where Kh. reads mA yalofaZu: both forms of the verb being used in this sense [as is implied in the Ḳ.]. (TA.)
5: see 1, last signification.

lafoZN, originally an inf. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) is used as a subst., (Mṣb,) signifying ‡ An expression; i. e. a word; [more precisely termed lafoZapN↓;] and also a collection of words, a phrase, or sentence; (I’Aḳ, &c.;) [each considered as such, without regard to its meaning; a word itself; and a phrase itself;] the latter also called lafoZN murak-abN, a compound expression, an expression composed of two or more words: (Expos. of the Ajroomeeyeh, by the sheykh Khálid;, &c.:) and malofaZN↓ signifies the same (TA:) pl. of the former OalofaAZN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) dim. OulayofaAZN: (Ḥar., p. 593) and of the latter malaAfiZ. (TA.) [Hence, lafoZFA wamaEonFI ‡ With respect to the word, or words, or wording, and the meaning: and with respect to the actual order of the words; and the order of the sense. And lafoZFA warutobapF ‡ With respect to the actual order of the words, and the order of the proper relative places. And lafoZFA wataqodiyrFA ‡ Literally and virtually. And laA waAHida lahu mino lafoZihi ‡ It has no singular formed of the same radical letter: i. e., it has no proper singular: said of a word such as qawomN and rahoTN, &c.]
See also lufaAZN.
lafoZapN: see lafoZN.
lafoZiI-N [Of, or relating to, a word, or collection of words, verbal:] opposed to maEonawiI-N.
lafaZaAnN Loquacious; a great talker: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

lufoAZN [app. a coll. gen. n., of which lufaAZapN↓, q. v., is the n. un., as seems to be indicated in the Ṣ, TA,] What is cast, or thrown, away; (M, TA;) as also lafoZN↓: the latter on the authority of IB. (TA.)
lifaAZN † Leguminous plants [put forth by the earth]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
lafiyZN and malofuwZN↓ Ejected; cast forth. (M, Ḳ.)
‡ [Uttered, spoken forth, or pronounced.]

lufaAZapN What is ejected, or cast forth, from the mouth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) such as particles of the toothstick, or stick with which the teeth are cleaned: (TA:) and what is cast, or thrown, away, of food: pl. lufaAZaAtN: (Ḥar, p. 180:) see also lufaAZN.
Also, ‡ A remain, remainder, or residue, of a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) little in quality. (TA.)
laAfiZN [act. part. n. of 1: fem. with p {laAfiZapN}]. You say, fulAanN laAfiZN ‡ Such a one is dying. (TA.)

All-aAfiZapu The she-goat, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or ewe; (M, Ḳ;) because she is called to be milked, while ruminating, and thereupon ejects her cud, and comes joyfully to be milked: (T,* Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) or the bird that feeds her young one from her beak; because she puts forth what is in her inside and gives it for food: (Ṣ, Ḳ *:) or the domestic cock; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because he takes the grain with his beak, and does not eat it, but throws it to the hen: (Ḳ:) or ‡ the mill; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) because it casts forth what it grinds, (T, TA,) of the flour: (TA:) or ‡ the sea; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also laAfiZapu, determinate [as a proper name]; (Ḳ;) because it casts forth (Ṣ, M) what is in it, (M,) [namely] ambergris and jewels: (Ṣ:) in this last sense, and as applied to the cock, (Ṣgh,) the p is to give intensiveness to the signification. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.) It has one or another of these significations in the saying, AsomaHu mino laAfiZapK [More liberal, or bountiful, than a she-goat,, &c.,] (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OasoxaI mino laAfiZapK (M, TA) and Oajowadu mino laAfiZapK [which mean the same]. (TA.) laAfiZapN also signifies Any bird that feeds his female, (T,) or that feeds his young bird, (M, Ḳ,) from his beak. (T, M, Ḳ.) And All-aAfiZapu ‡ The earth; because it casts forth the dead. (TA.) And ‡ The present world; because it casts forth those who are in it to the world to come. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
malofaZN: see lafoZN.
malofuwZN: see lafiyZN.

dictScrap.title: lfE / lfq / lfm / lq
dictScrap.label:
[lfE, lfq, lfm and lq
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 2. lq-bhu bikacaA, inf. n. taloqiybN, He called him, or named him, by such a by-name, or surname, or nickname; he surnamed him, or nicknamed him, so. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See laqabN.

lq-b AlUisoma biAlfiEoli [i. e., biAlfaACi waAlEayoni waAll-aAmi] He called the noun by an appellation in which its radical letters were represented by f, E, and l; this appellation being its measure; as when jaworabN is called fawoEalN. (TA.) [But this signification belongs to the conventional language of lexicology and grammar.]
3. laAqabahu, inf. n. mulaAqabapN, He called him by a byname, surname, or nickname; the latter doing to him the like. (TA.)
5. tlq-b bikacaA He was by-named, surnamed, or nicknamed, so. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See laqabN.
6. talaAqabuwA They called one another by by-names, surnames, or nicknames. (TA.)

laqabN A by-name; a surname; a nickname; syn. nabazN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: in this sense forbidden: (Mṣb:) it is said in the Ḳur, xlix., 11, laA tanaAbazuwA biQloOaloqaAbi Call not one another by nicknames; i. e., let not one of you call another by a name which he dislikes: (Jel:) also a by-name, or surname, which is not one of reproach:
such are the surnames given to certain Imáms; AlOanomaXu and AlOaxofaXu and AlA-aEoraju and the like; and such are not forbidden, because by them is not meant reproach, or disparagement, but they are meant as mere appellations given with the approval of the persons to whom they are applied. (Mṣb.) [A laqab is distinguished from a kunoyap, q. v.] Pl. OaloqaAbN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[laqabu QsomK The appellation given to a noun by substituting f, E, and l for its radical letters. See 2.]

1. laqava, [aor. _u {yaloquvu},] inf. n. laqovN; and lq-v↓, inf. n. taloqiyvN; He mixed [a thing]. (Ḳ.) [The former verb is as above accord. to the TḲ: but it seems to be implied in the Ḳ that it is laqiva, aor. laqiva, as well in the above sense as in that here following.]
laqiva, aor. _i {yaloqivu}, inf. n. laqovN, He took [a thing] quickly, and altogether. (Ḳ.) But this is not of established authority. (TA.)
2: see 1.

1. laqiHato, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaloqaHu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. laqaHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and laqoHN (Ḳ) and laqaAHN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and luqiHato biAlowaladi, in the pass. form; (Mṣb;) She (a camel) conceived, or became pregnant; (Mṣb, TA;) received [into her womb] the seed of the stallion. (Ḳ.)
laqiHato (inf. n. laqaHN, syn. HabalN, Ḳ, TA: in the CK jabalN:) ‡ She (a woman) conceived, or became pregnant. (Sh, T, L.)

AimoraOapN sariyEapu All-aqaHi A woman quick in conceiving, or becoming pregnant. The like is said with respect to any female. Perhaps the word thus used has this signification properly, or perhaps tropically. (TA.)

Oasar-ato laqaHFA, and laqaAHFA, She (a camel) concealed her having conceived, or become pregnant: i. e., she did not show signs of her having conceived by raising her tail and elevating her nose. (L.)

laqiHati Aln-axiylu, or luqiHat, (as in different copies of the Ṣ,) ‡ [The palm-trees became fecundated by the process termed UiloqaAHN: see 4]: and of a single palm-tree (naxolapN) you say laqiHato, or luqiHato, without teshdeed; (so, again, in different copies of the Ṣ;) and talaq-aHato↓. (Ṣ, art. Obr)
laqiHa AlEijaAfu, inf. n. laqaHN, ‡ The lands in which was no good became fecundated. (L.) [See also OaEojafu.]
laqiHati AlHarobu: see a verse cited voce En.
2: see 4.

4. AlqH AlfaHolu Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. UiloqaAHN; (Mṣb;) and lq-HhA↓, (A,) [inf. n. taloqiyHN;] The stallion-camel made the she-camel to conceive, or become pregnant; impregnated her; got her with young. (Mṣb.)

AlqH Aln-axolapa, inf. n. UiloqaAHN, [and quasi-inf. n. laqaAHN, q. v.; et vide infra;] and lq-HhA↓, inf. n. taloqiyHN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, A, Ḳ;) and laqaHahaA↓, inf. n. laqoHN; (Ḳ;) ‡ He fecundated the palm-tree by means of the laqaAH↓, or spadix of the male tree, which is bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]: (A:) or, by inserting a stalk of a raceme of the male tree into the spathe [of the female, after shaking off the pollen of the former upon the spadix of the female; for such is the general practice]: this is done in the following manner: you leave the spathe of the [female] palm-tree two or three nights after its bursting open: then you take a stalk of a raceme of the male tree, which is best if old, of the preceding year, and insert it into the spadix [of the female, after shaking off the pollen, as above mentioned]; and this you do according to a certain measure: it should not be done but by a man acquainted with the manner of proceeding in this case; for if he be ignorant, and do too much, he turns the spathe, and mars it; and if he do too little, many of the dates produced will be without stones; and if he do it not at all to the palm-tree, he will derive no advantage from the spadix thereof that year: (L:) laqaHN↓ is the name of that which is taken from the male palm-tree (AlfuH-aAl: so in the L: in the Ḳ, AlfaHol:) to be inserted in the other, [namely the spathe of the female]. (L, Ḳ.) [See also laqaAHN. In the CK, for Uisomu maA Ouxica Alx, we find Asm mACK Axc Alx, giving a different and false meaning.] jaMCanaA zamanu All-aqaAHi, or Alt-aloqiyHi↓, The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees has come to us. (L.)

OaloqaHati Alr-iyHu Als-aHaAba (Ṣ) ‡ The wind impregnated, or fecundated, the cloud, or clouds; (L;) and in like manner, AlqHt Alr-iyaAHu AlX-ajara wanaHowahu [The winds fecundated the trees] (Ḳ) [and the like]. (TA.)
AlqH bayonahumo Xar-FA ‡ He engendered, or caused, evil, or mischief, between them. (A.)
jar-aba AlOumuwra falaq-aHato↓ Eaqolahu ‡ [He became experienced in affairs, and they fecundated his intellect]. (A.)
Aln-aZaru fiI EawaAqibi QloOumwuri taloqiyHu↓ QloEuquwli ‡ [Consideration of the results, or issues, of things is (a means of) fecundation of the intellects]. (A.)
laA tuloqiHo siloEataka biAlOayomaAni ‡ [Make not thy merchandise productive of a high price by means of oaths]. (A.)

5. tlq-Ht She (a camel) pretended that she had conceived, or become pregnant, (by raising her tail, in order that the stallion might not approach her, TA,) when this was not really the case. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.
10. AstlqHt Aln-axolapu ‡ The palm-tree attained to the proper period for its being fecundated by the process termed UiloqaAHN: [see 4: or required to be so fecundated]. (Ḳ.)
laqaHN: inf. n. of 1., q. v.
see OaloqaHa Aln-axolapa, and see laqaAHN.
laqoHapN: see liqoHapN and laquwHN.
liqoHapN (Ḳ) and laqoHapN↓ (TA) † A woman suckling; or a woman who suckles. (Ḳ.)
See laquwHN.

hom.sense: laqaAHN ‡ The thing [namely flowers or pollen] with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) taken from a male palm-tree; (L;) the spadix of a male palm-tree, (A, Ḳ,) with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, it being bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]. (A.) [See also laqaHN, voce OaloqaHa, and liqaAHN]
HaI-N laqaAHN A tribe that does not submit to kings, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and that has not been governed by a king: (L:) or, that has not suffered captivity in the time of paganism. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.

entry.sense: liqaAHN The semen genitale (L, Ḳ) of a stallion camel, and horse, and ‡ of a man. (L.) I’Ab, being asked respecting a man who had two wives, one of whom suckled a boy, and the other a girl, [not his own children,] whether the boy might marry the girl, answered “No; because the lqAH [i. e., liqaAH or laqaAH↓, as shown below,] is one:” meaning, says Lth, that the semen genitale which impregnated them both, and which was the source of the milk of both, was one, and that the two sucklings had thus become as though they were the children of the two women's husband: but, says Az, lqAH may here be a quasi-inf. n., syn. with UiloqaAHN; like EaTaMCN and UiEoTaMCN, &c.: (L:) [and the like is said in the Mṣb.] laqaAHN↓ and liqaAHN, with fet-ḥ and kesr, are substs. from OaloqaHa, [q. v.] syn. with UiloqaAHN, signifying impregnation, or the getting with young; and so in the answer of I’Ab above mentioned. (Mṣb.)
laquwHN A camel (Ṣ, Ḳ) itself: (Ṣ:) pl. liqaAHN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See laAqiHN.

laquwHN and liqoHapN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and laqoHapN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to a she-camel, i. q. HaluwbN [meaning Milch, and a milch camel]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but Az says, that the former only is used as an epithet; you say nAqp laquwHN, and not nAqpN liqoHapN, but hecihi liqoHapN fulaAnK: (TA:) or laquwHN is [an epithet] applied to a she-camel during the first two or three months after her having brought forth; and after this she is termed labuwnN: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and accord. to some, liqoHapN↓ signifies a milch camel abounding with milk: or a she-camel from the time when the hump of her young one becomes fat, until the expiration of seven months, when she weans her young one, and this she does at the [auroral] rising of Canopus: (TA:) [which rising, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight was between the 30th of July and the 12th of August:]
also liqoHapN↓ and laqoHapN↓ a she-camel that has lately brought forth: (L:) pl. of laquwHN, liqaAHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and laqaAYiHu; (ISh;) and pl. of liqoHapN↓ (and of laqoHapN↓, Ḳ, TA,) liqaHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and liqaAHN. (ISh, Th, Mṣb.)

The Arabs also said liqaAHaAni OasowadaAni [Two black herds of milch camels], like as they said qaTiyEaAni; for they said liqaAHN waAHidapN in like manner as they said qaTiyEN waAHidN and UibilN waAHidapN. (Ṣ.)

Oadir-uwA liqoHapa↓ Almusolimiyna ‡ Milk ye the milch camel of the Muslims: occurring in a trad., alluding to the tribute (faIoC and xaraAj) whence were derived the stipends and fixed appointments of the persons addressed, and to the collecting it with equity. (TA.)
laq-aAHN A fecundator of palm-trees. (Az, TA in art. jnI.)

lAqiHN (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and laquwHN↓ (Ḳ) and maloquwHapN↓ (Mṣb) A she-camel having just conceived, or become pregnant; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also qaAriHN: afterwards, when her pregnancy has become manifestly apparent, she is termed xalifapN: (IAạr:) pl. of the former lawaAqiHu (Ḳ) and luq-aHN; (TA;) and of the second, luquHN. (L, Ḳ, TA: in the CK luq-aHN.)

riyaAHN lawaAqiHu (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) ‡ Pregnant winds; so called because they bear the water and the clouds, and turn the latter over and about, and then cause them to send down rain; (TA;) or because they become pregnant, and then impregnate the clouds: (IJ:) the sing. is riyHN laAqiHN, the contr. of which is termed riyHN EaqiymN [or “a barren wind”]: (ISd:) or ryH lAqH signifies caAtu laqalaAHK [possessing that which impregnates]; like as dirohamN waAzinN signifies cuw wazoni; rajulN raAmiHN, cuw rumoHK: (AHeyth:) or ryAH lwAqH signifies impregnating, or fecundating, winds; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also malaAqiHu↓ [pl. of muloqiHapN]: (Ḳ:) or it is not allowable to say malaAqiHu; (Ṣ;) but this is the regular form of the word; because the wind impregnates the clouds; (IJ;) and thus lwAqH is extr.: or, as some say, the proper original word is muloqiHapN; but the winds do not impregnate unless they are themselves pregnant; as though they were pregnant with good, and, when they raised the clouds, transmitted to them that good. (Ṣ.)
HarobN laAqiHN (Ḳ) ‡ War pregnant [with great events.] (TA.)
muloqiHN A stallion camel: pl. malaAqiHu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See laAqiHN.
‡ A man to whom offspring is born. Occurring in a trad. (TA.)
muloqaHapN A female camel that has her young one in her belly: pl. malaAqiHu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a pass. part. n. from OaloqaHa. (Mṣb.)
AlmalaAqiyHu is also used (sometimes, TA) to signify The mothers: and its sing. is maloquwHapN. (Ḳ.)
See laAqiHN.

1. laqisato nafosuhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaloqasu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. laqasN, (Ṣ, TA,) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; or became heavy; syn. gavato, [q. v.,] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and xabuvato; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) mina AlX-aIoCi in consequence of the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Moḥammad desired his followers to use this expression instead of xabuvato nafosuhu, which he disliked. (Ḳ, TA.)
With UilI AlX-aIoCi following it, His soul strove with him to incline him to the thing, (Ḳ,) and became greedy for it. (TA.) [But Az seems to disapprove of this explanation.]
laqisapN, as an epithet applied to nafosN, is the part. n. of laqisato in the [first and] second of the senses explained above. (TA.)

1. laqaTahu, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaloquTu}, inf. n. laqoTN, (Mṣb, TA,) He picked it up, took it up, raised it, (Mgh,) or took it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the ground, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) without trouble or fatigue; as also AltqThu↓: (Ṣ:) or both signify he took it from a place where it was not thought to be; this being the primary signification: and hence, he took it. (Mṣb.) It is said of a man: and you say also, laqaTa AlT-aAYiru AlHab-a [The bird picked up from the ground the grains]. (Mṣb.) The Arabs say to a calumniator, Uin-a Einodaka diykFA yalotaqiTu↓ AlHaSaI [Verily thou hast a cock that picks up pebbles]. (TA.) And it is said in a proverb, OaSayoda Alqunofuci Oamo laqoTahu [Is it by the hunting of the hedgehog or the picking up thereof from the ground?] applied to a poor man who becomes rich suddenly. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov. (i. 726,) OaSayodu Alqunofuci Oamo luqaTapN: and there asserted to be said of him who finds a thing which he had not sought: or, accord. to Sharafed-Deen, of a thing of the nature of which we may be uncertain.] You say also, laqaTotu AlEilomi mina Alkutubi † [I picked up science, or knowledge, from books;] I acquired science, or knowledge, from this and that book. (Mṣb.) And laqaTotu OaSaAbiEahu † I took off his fingers, by cutting, without [the main part of] the hand. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 3. mulaAqaTapN A horse's lifting the legs all together in the pace called taqoriyb: (AO, Ḳ:*) or, in the pace called xabab, of a horse, it is similar to munaAqalapN. (JK.)

Also, (Ḳ,) and liqaATN↓, (TA,) The being over against, or facing. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, daAruhu biliqaATi daAriI His house is over against, or faces, my house. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) And laqiytuhu liqaATAF I met him face to face. (IAạr.)

entry.sense: 5. tlq-T fulaAnN Alt-amora, or Alv-amara, (Ṣ, accord. to different copies, and Ḳ,*) Such a one, [picked up, or] took up from the ground, from this and that place, the dates, or the fruits. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
8. AltqThu: see 1, in two places.
Also, He collected it. (Mṣb.)

And ‡ He stumbled upon it, or lighted on it, (Ḳ, TA,) unexpectedly, (TA,) without seeking; (Ḳ, TA;) such a thing, for instance, as a well, and herbage. (TA.) You say also, waradotu AlX-aIoCa QlotiqaATFA ‡ I came upon the thing unexpectedly, or unawares; (Ṣ, TA:) and laqiytuhu QlotiqaATFA ‡ I met him unexpectedly: (TA:) AltqATA in this sense being one of those inf. ns. which are used as denotatives of state. (Sb, TA.)

laqaTN What is picked up, or taken from the ground, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also luqoTapN↓ and luqaTapN↓ and luqaATapN↓: (Ḳ:) or ↓this last signifies what one picks up, of lost property; as also luqaATN↓, with the p elided; and luqaTapN↓ like ruTabapN: (Mṣb:) or luqaATapN↓ signifies also what falls, or drops, of a thing that is worthless, (Ḳ, TA,) or paltry, and is taken by any one who chooses to take it: (TA:) and the same, what is picked up from the stumps of the branches of palm-trees, [app. meaning dates picked up thence,] after the cutting off of the dates: (TA:) IAth says, that luqaTapN↓, with damm to the l and fet-ḥ to the q, is often mentioned in trads., and signifies property which is found: (TA:) Az says, that luqaTapN, with fet-ḥ to the q, signifies a thing which one finds dropped, or thrown down, and takes; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and that all the lexicologists and skilful grammarians say so; (Mṣb;) and in like manner, AʼObeyd, on the authority of Aṣ and of El-Aḥmar; (TA;)
only Lth, of all whom he has heard, saying that it is luqoTapN↓, with sukoon; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and Fr: (TA:) IF and El-Fárábee and others mention only luqaTapN↓; and some reckon the pronunciation with sukoon as an error of the vulgar; and the reason is this; that the original word is luqaATapN↓, which, in consequence of its being in frequent use, as applied to what is picked up in plundering, is contracted, sometimes, by the elision of the p, into luqaATN↓, and sometimes, by the elision of the A into luqaTapN↓; and if they made the q quiescent, there would be two alterations in the word, and such double alteration does not exist in chaste language: (Mṣb:) IB, however, says that luqoTapN↓ is correct; and he approves it; because fuEolapN has the sense of a pass. part. n., as in the instance of DuHokapN; and fuEalapN has the sense of an act. part. n., as in the instance of DuHakapN; and that it occurs in poetry: and IAth observes, that some say thus; but that luqaTapN↓ is more common and more correct. (TA.) Anything that is scattered, of ears of corn, or of fruit; n. un. with p {laqaTapN}: (TA:) what is picked up, or taken from the ground, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by men, (Ṣ,) of ears of corn; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also luqaATN↓, with damm: (Ṣ:) and laqaATN↓, like saHaAbN, the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss, (AḤn, Ḳ,) and which men pick up. (AḤn.) What is picked up from a mine: (Mṣb:) pieces of gold found in a mine; (Ḳ;) or such are termed laqaTu maEodinK: (Ṣ:) or laqaTN signifies pieces of gold, or of silver, like what are termed Xacor, and larger, in mines; which are the best thereof: and one says cahabN laqaTN: (Lth:) and mulotaqaTN↓, also, signifies gold found in a mine. (TA.) You say also, fiI hecaA AlmakaAni laqaTN mina AlmarotaEi In this place is some small quantity of pasturage. (Ṣ.) And fiI AlOaroDi laqaTN lilomaAli In the land is pasturage not much in quantity for the beasts. (TA.) The pl. is OaloqaATN. (TA.)
luqoTapN: see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence.

Accord. to Lth, it [also] signifies A man who repeatedly and perseveringly seeks after things to be picked up, and picks them up: (TA:) and some say, that luqaTapN↓ signifies one who picks up: but the more common and correct signification of this latter is “property which is found,” as before stated. (IAth.)
luqaTapN: see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence:
and see luqoTapN.
laqaATN: see laqaTN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
luqaATN: see laqaTN, in three places.
liqaATN: see 3.

[The act of picking up the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss;] the act denoted in the explanation of laqaATN. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) You say, huwa yataEay-aXu biAlil-qaATi Eani All-aqaATi [He constrains himself to obtain the means of life, or he obtains what is barely sufficient for his sustenance, by picking up, or gleaning, from the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks have missed]. (TḲ: but there given without any syll. signs.) [If the reading intended be biAll-aqaATi Eani All-iqaATi, the meaning of liqaATN is The act of missing ears of corn with the reapinghook; as is implied in the Ḳ, where laqaATN is imperfectly explained: but this I think improbable.] laqaATN and liqaATN are [respectively] like HaSaAdN [as signifying what is “reaped”] and HiSaAdN [as signifying the act of “reaping”]. (TA.)
laqiyTN i. q. maloquwTN↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. A thing that is picked up, taken up, raised, (Mgh,) or taken, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the ground, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or from a place where it was not thought to be. (Mṣb.)

And, generally, (Mgh,) A foundling; or child that is cast out, (Az, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and found by a man, (Az, TA,) or picked up; (Ṣ;) or because it is cast out with the object of its being picked up: (Mgh:) not what Lth asserts it to be; i. e. a child that is cast out in the roads, and there found, whose father and mother are unknown: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Az, TA:) and maloquwTN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) [pl. of the former, luqaTaMCu.]
Also, A well upon which one lights unexpectedly, or unawares, (Lth, Ḳ,) without seeking it. (Lth.)
luqaATapN: see laqaTN, first sentence, in four places.

laqiyTapN applied to a man, and to a woman, ‡ Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean; (Ḳ, TA;) as also laAqiTapN↓ applied to a man; (TA;) and so saAqiTN maAqiTN laAqiTN↓, used together. (L in art. sqT.) It occurs in this sense preceded by saqiyTapN; but you say saqiyTN when alone. (TA.)
laq-aATN: see laAqiTN.
laq-aATapN: see laAqiTN.

hom.sense: laAqiTN and in an intensive sense laq-aATN↓ and [in a doubly intensive sense] laq-aATapN↓ A man [who picks up things from the ground; and the second, who does so much, or often; and the third, who does so very much, or very often: or] who takes things from places where they were not thought to be: (Mṣb:) and all signify a man who picks up the ears of corn [that fall] when the crop is reaped, and [the fruit that falls] when the ripe dates are cut from the raceme: (TA:) and the first and second, a bird that picks up grains. (Mṣb.)

likul-i saAqiTapK laAqiTapN↓ For every saying that falls from one, there is a person who will take it up: (Mṣb in art. sqT:) or for every word that falls from the mouth of the speaker, there is a person who will hear it and pick it up and publish it: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) a proverb, (TA,) relating to the guarding of the tongue: (Ḳ:) the p in lAqTp is to give intensiveness to the meaning, (Mṣb, in art. sqT,) or for the purpose of assimilation: (Mṣb in that art., and in the present one:) if you say likul-i DaAYiEK, or the like, you say laAqiTN. (Mṣb in the present art.)

laAqiTapN↓ AlHaSaI The qaAniSap [meaning stomach,, &c.,] of a bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which pebbles become collected: (Ṣ:) or the omasum (qib-p) of a sheep or goat [and the corresponding ventricle of a camel, as is shown in the TA in art. HSl; also called laq-aATapu AlHaSaI (see qurayoHaMCu);] because it conveys thereinto whatever it eats of earth and pebbles; (A, TA;) as also All-aAqiTapN [alone]. (TA.)

laAqiTN also signifies ‡ Any freedman, or emancipated slave: (Ḳ:) or the slave of a freedman. (Ṣ in art. mqT, and TA in art. sqT:) the slave of the lAqT is called maAqiTN; and the slave of the mAqT is called saAqiTN: and hence the saying, huwa saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (Ḳ, TA [but in the CK, for huwa we find banuw, with the necessary difference in what follows it.]) See art. sqT.
See also laqiyTapN: and see OaloqaATN, which may be a pl. of laAqiTN; as in luq-aATN, which is explained with OaloqaATN.
laAqiTapN: see laAqiTN, in two places:
and see also laqiyTapN.

entry.sense: † A small number of men, separated, or scattered, or dispersed. (Ṣ.)

[Also, perhaps as pl. of laAqiTN, like as OaSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN,] ‡ The refuse, or lowest, or basest, or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also luq-aATN↓ [which is doubtless a pl. of laAqiTN, like as suq-aATK is of saAqiTN, and muq-aATN of maAqiTN]. (IAạr, in TA, art. xXr.)
maloqaTN [A place where a thing is picked up:] a place where a thing is sought, or to be sought: a mine: (TA:) [pl. malAqiTu.]
OaSobaHato maraAEiynaA malaAqiTa mina Aljadobi Our places of pasturage became dried up, and destitute of herbage, by reason of the drought. (Aṣ.)
miloqaTN A thing with which, (Ḳ,) or in which, (Jm,) one picks up, or takes up, from the ground: (Jm, Ḳ;) as also miloqaATN↓. (TA.)
miloqaATN: see miloqaTN.
The [instrument called] minoqaAX, (Ḳ, TA,) with which hair is plucked up. (TA.)
maloquwTN: see laqiyTN, in two places. IAth explains maAlN maloquwTN as signifying property found. (TA.)
mulotaqaTN: see laqaTN, last sentence but two.
Also, applied to a thing, i. q. saAqiTN † [Vile, mean, or paltry]. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: lqE / lqf / lqm / lqn / lqI / lk
dictScrap.label:
[lqE, lqf, lqm, lqn, lqI and lk
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. lakaOa, aor. _a {yalokaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lakoCN, (TA,) He beat a person (Ḳ) with a whip. (TA.)
lakaOa bihi AlOaroDa He cast him upon the ground. (AZ, Ṣ.) [See zakaOa, and lataOa.]
lakaOahu He prostrated him. (Ḳ.)
lakaOahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (Ḳ:) like lafaOahu. (T.)
lakiYa, aor. _a {yalokaOu}, He stayed, dwelt, or abode, (Ḳ,) in a place: like lakiIa. (TA.) lkY bimawoDiEK He kept, or remained fixed, in a place. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tlk-O Ealayohi He excused himself to him; he pleaded an excuse to him. (Ḳ.)
tlk-O Eanohu He was slow to do it; delayed to do it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) excused himself, or pleaded an excuse, for not doing it; refused to do it, or abstained from doing it. (TA.)
malokabapN A she-camel compact in flesh: (Ḳ:) or abounding with fat, and compact in flesh. (AA, T.)
The conduct of a pimp: syn. qiyaAdapN (L.)

1. lakava, [aor. _u {yalokuvu},] inf. n. lakovN (and likaAvN, IAạr), He struck, or smote; (Ḳ;) accord. to IAạr, who does not particularize the hand, nor the foot: (TA:) or, with his hand, or his foot, accord. to some: (TA:) or, with [perhaps a mistake for upon] the mouth. (Kr.) [See also lkd.]
lakatahu, [aor. _u {yalokuvu},] He overburdened him. (Ḳ.)
lakiva, aor. _a {yalokavu}, [inf. n. lakavN,] He (a camel) was affected with the disorder called lakavN, or lukaAvN. (Ḳ.)
lakiva bihi, aor. _a {yalokavu}, It (dirt [see lakovN]) adhered to it; (Ḳ;) i. e., to the vessel. (TA.) [See also lakida and lakiEa.]
lakovN The dirt of milk, which congeals upon the edge of the vessel, and is removed with the hand. (TA.)
lakavN and lukaAvN↓ (as also nukaAvN, TA,) A disorder in the mouths of camels, resembling pustules. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

lukaAvapN↓, A disorder that attacks sheep or goats in the sides of the mouth and in the lips, resembling an ulcer; happening on their first cropping plants when they are short, with small branches. (L.)
naAqapN lakivapN A fat she-camel. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: lukaAvN A shining stone in gypsum. (Fr, Ḳ.)
See lakavN.

entry.sense: lukaAvapN: see lakavN.
luk-aAvN [pl. of laAkivN?] Preparers of gypsum: (Ḳ:) not those who traffick therein. (TA.)
lukaAviI-N A man (TA) very white: (Ḳ:) from lukaAvN as signifying a shining stone in gypsum. (TA.)
1. lakida Ealayohi, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and bihi, (L,) aor. _a {yalokadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lakadN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, L;) and tlk-d↓ bh; (A;) It (dirt) clave, or stuck, to him, or it. (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
lakida bifiyhi It (a glutinous thing that had been eaten of) left part of its substance, or its colour, sticking to his (the eater's) mouth. (L.)
lakida It (his hair) became compacted together, or matted, (L,) by reason of dirt. (A.)
lakida bihi, and Altkd↓, He kept to, or clave to, and did not quit, him, or it. (L.) See also 3.
3. lAkdhu He kept, clave, or clung, to him. (L.)
5. tlk-d It (a thing) clave together, one part to another. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
He became thick (and compact, TA,) in his flesh. (Ḳ.)
See 1.
tlk-dhu He embraced him; put his arms round his neck. (Aṣ, L, Ḳ.)
8. Uilotakada see 1.
milokadN A thing resembling a muduq- [or pestle], with which one bruises, brays, or pounds. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

1. lakazahu, aor. _u {yalokuzu}, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. lakozN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He struck him upon the breast (AO, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) with the fist: (AO, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) and upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin]: (A, Ḳ:) and upon the neck: (Ḳ:) or upon any part of the body with the fist: (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or with the extremities of the fingers: (TA, art. lqz:) he pushed, or impelled, or repelled, him: (TA, ibid.:) he thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]: (TA, art. lz:) lakozN is also syn. with wakozN [which has several significations, some of which are indentical with some explained above]. (Ḳ.) You say also, lakazahu bijumoEi kaf-ihi He struck him upon the breast, or the part called Hanak, with his fist. (A.)
3. lAkzhu, inf. n. mulaAkazapN, [He contended with him in striking upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin,, &c., with the fists.] (A, TA.)
6. tlAkzA [They two contended in striking each other upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin,, &c., with their fists]. (A, TA.)
lakozapN A blow upon the breast, (A, Mgh,) and upon the part beneath the chin, [&c.,] (A,) with the fist. (Mgh.)
mulak-azN ‡ A low, an abject, or a despicable, man, who is repelled (A, TA) from the doors. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: lkE / lkm / lkn / lkI
dictScrap.label:
[lkE, lkm, lkn and lkI
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: lawolabN: see art. lb.
mulawolabN i. q. mirowadN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and the like. (Ṣ.) Of the measure mufawoEalN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, faEawoEalN. (TA.)

dictScrap.label:
[lm
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. lamaOahu, and lamaOa Ealayohi, aor. _a {yalomaOu}, He smote his hand upon it, [or laid his hand upon it, or seized it,] openly or secretly. (Ḳ.)
lamaOa AlX-aIoCa He took the whole thing; took it entirely. (Ḳ.)
lamaOa AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. lamoCN, (TA,) He glanced, or took a slight look at the thing; beheld it quickly: like lamaHahu. (Ḳ.)
4. AlmO Ealayohi He (a thief, TA) took it away privily. (Ḳ.) [See also OalomaI.]
AlmO EalaI-a Haq-iI He denied me my right, or due. (Ḳ.)
AlmOt Ald-awaAb-u AlmakaAna (Ṣ) [in the Ḳ, biAlamkaAni; but this appears, from what is said in the Ṣ and the TA, to be wrong;] The beasts of carriage left the place bare of pasture. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AlmO Elyh, (Ḳ,) or bihi, (Ṣ, L,) He took, or got, possession of it; took it, got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession: syn. UiXotamala Ealayohi: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he took it away; went away with it. (Ḳ.) AlmO EalaI AlX-aIoCi He got possession of the thing. (L.) cahaba vawobiI famaA OadoriI mano AlmO bh [My garment is gone, and I know not who has taken, or got, possession of it; or who has taken it away]. (Ṣ.) The phrase without negation is also used. (ISk, Ṣ.) [See also 8.]
5. tlm-Ot AlOaroDu bihi, (Ḳ,) and Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The earth enclosed him; was made even over him: and concealed him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 8.

hom.sense: 8. AltmO bimaA fiI Aljafonapi, and AlmO↓, and tlm-O↓, He took to himself the contents of the bowl. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also AltmE and AlmE and tlm-E.]
OulotumiYa lawonuhu His colour altered, or became altered. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) UilotamaOa is also mentioned as having the same signification. (TA.) [See also AltmE and AltmI.]

entry.sense: malomuWapN A place in which a thing is taken (yuWoxacu, as in some copies of the Ḳ) or found (yuwjadu, as in other copies of the Ḳ).
A sportsman's, or hunter's, or fowler's, or fisherman's net. (Ḳ, TA.)

1. lamaja, (aor. _u {yalomuju} S, M,) inf. n. lamojN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He ate: or he ate with the extremity of the mouth: (M:) or he ate with the extremities of his mouth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he took fodder, or dry herbage, with the extremity of his mouth: (T:) AZ says, I know not All-amoj except as the act of asses, and it is like All-amos, [probably a mistake for All-ahos, or its syn. All-aHos,] or signifies more than this latter word. (AḤn.)
lamaja, inf. n. lamojN, Inivit feminam. (Ḳ.)

2. lam-ajahu, inf. n. talomiyjN, He fed him with something whereby to content, or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC: see lumojapN. (TA.) And see lam-aZahu: and Eaj-alotumo: and Eas-ala.
maA lam-ajuwA Dayofahumo biXaIoCK They did not feed their guest with anything whereby to allay the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal. (Ṣ.)
5. tlm-j He ate something whereby to content, or satisfy, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC. (Ḳ.) [See lumojapN: and see also lamaAjN.]

Accord. to AA, it is like talam-aZa; [He searched repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of food in his mouth, and put forth his tongue and licked his lips with it;] and one says, raOayotuhu yatalam-aju biAlT-aEaAmi, i. e. ytlm-Z [I saw him searching repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, &c.]; and Aṣ says the like. (Ṣ.)

samojN lamojN, (Ḳ,) or XaIoCN samojN lamojN (Ṣ,) and samijN lamijN↓, and samiyjN lamiyjN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in each of these expressions, the latter word is an imitative sequent: (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [app. Very ugly: in the TA it is said, that these epithets are applied to a man, and signify caw-aAqN, app. meaning one who tastes much: and in the L it is said, that rajulN lamijN↓, after the manner of a relative noun, signifies caw-aAqN]. See lamoHN.
lamijN: see lamojN.
lumojapN: see lamaAjN.
Also [An early portion of food, being] That with which one contents, or diverts, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC. (Ḳ.) See sulofapN.
lamaAjN The least (OadonaI) [kind, or quantity,] of food, or of what is eaten: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and sometimes, of beverage. (TA.)
maA talam-ajotu Einodahu bilamaAjK, (Ṣ, L,) and lamuwjK↓, and lumojapK↓, (L,) I ate not anything at his abode: (L:) and maA cuqotu XamaAjAF walaA lamaAjFA, (Ṣ, L,) I tasted not anything. (Ṣ, L.)
lamuwjN: see lamaAjN.
lamiyjN One who eats much; a great eater. (Ḳ.)
Is qui multum coït: as also laAmijN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also lamojN.
laAmijN: see lamiyjN.
malaAmiju: i. q. malaAgima: (i. e., Ṣ;) The parts around the mouth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
rumoHN mulam-ajN A smoothed spear. (Ḳ.)

1. lamaHahu, (Ṣ,) or lamaHa Uilayohi, aor. _a {yalomaHu}; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ), inf. n. lamoHN; (Mṣb;) and AlmH↓, (L, Ḳ,) or AlmHhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and AltmHhu↓; (Ṣ;) He glanced, or took a light, or slight, look, at him or it; (Ṣ;) like lamaOahu; (Nh;) snatched a sight of him or it unawares: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, accord. to some, lamaHa signifies he looked; and AlmHhu↓, he made him to look; but the former explanation is the more correct: or lamaHa is only said of one looking from a distance. (L.)
lamaHotuhu biAlbaSari I directed (Saw-abotu) my sight towards him. (Mṣb.)
lamaHa AlbaSaru The sight extended to a thing. (Mṣb.)
lamaHa, aor. _a {yalomaHu}, inf. n. lamoHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and lamaHaAnN and talomaAHN, (Ḳ,) It (lightning, and a star,) shone; gleamed; glistened; i. q. lamaEa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
3. laAmaHahu, inf. n. mulaAmaHapN, [He glanced at him, or viewed him lightly, or slightly, or snatched sights of him unawares, reciprocally]. (A.)
4. AlmHhu He made him to glance, or to take a light, or slight, look; expl. by jaEalahu yalomaHa, (Ḳ,) and jaEalahu mim-ano yalomaHu. (TA.)
See 1.

OalomaHati AlmaroOapu mino wajohihaA, (inf. n. UilomaAHN, TA,) The woman allowed herself [or her face] to be glanced at, or to be viewed lightly, or slightly: so does a beautiful woman, displaying, and then concealing, her beauties. (T, Ḳ.)
8. OalotumiHa baSaruhu His sight was taken away. (Ḳ.)
See 1.
fulaAnN samoHN lamoHN, and samiyHN lamiyHN↓: see art. smH. [lamoHN and lamiyHN in these cases seem to be merely imitative sequents.]
laOuriyan-aka lamoHFA baASirFA ‡ I will assuredly show thee a manifest, or an evident, thing, matter, or affair. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [See also art. bSr.]
lamoHapN, subst. from lamaHa, (Ṣ, L,) A glance, or light or slight look. (L.)
lamoHapN A shining, gleaming, or glistening, of lightning. (Ṣ.)

fiI fulaAnK lamoHapN mino Oabiyhi In such a one is a likeness, or point of resemblance, to his father: then they said malAmiHu↓ mino Abyh, (Ṣ,) signifying likenessess, or points of resemblance; forming an extr. pl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as though from another word than lamoHapN: (Ṣ:) they did not say malomaHapN. (TA.)
malaAmiHu↓ also signifies What appear of the beauties and defects of the face (Ḳ) of a human being: or the parts thereof that are glanced at, or viewed lightly or quickly. (TA.)
lamuwHN: see laAmiHN.
lamiyHN: see lamoHN.
lam-aAHN: see laAmiHN.
lum-aAHN Sharp hawks; syn. SuquwrN cakiy-apN. (IAạr, T, Ḳ, [in the CK, zakiy-ap].)
laAmiHN and lamuwHN↓ and lam-aAHN↓ Lightning, and a star, shining; gleaming; glistening: (Ḳ:) [but the second and third are intensive epithets, signifying shining much;, &c.]
OaboyaDu lam-aAHN↓ ‡ Intensely white. (A.)
laAmiHu EiTofayohi A self-admiring man, who looks at his sides. (M, F.)
OalomaHiI-N A man (TA) who glances much, or frequently takes light, or slight looks. (Ḳ.)
malaAmiHu: see lamoHapN.

hom.sense: 1. lamazahu, aor. _i {yalomizu} and _u {yalomuzu}, inf. n. lamozN, He made a sign to him with the eye, or the like, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) as the head, and the lip, with low speech. (TA.) This is the original signification. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) He blamed, upbraided, or reproached, him; he found fault with him: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he did so in his face: (TA:) or he met him with blaming, upbraiding, reproaching or finding fault: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) or he spoke evil of him, or spoke of him in a manner that he disliked, mentioning vices or faults as chargeable to him, either behind his back or before his face, though it might be with truth; syn. UigotaAbahu. (TA.) The two forms of the aor. occur in readings of the words of the Ḳur., [ix. 58,] waminohumo mano yalomizuka fiI AlS-adaqaAti and yalomuzuka, (Ṣ, TA,) And of them are those who blame thee with respect to the division of the alms: (Bḍ, Jel:) and Ibn-Ketheer reads yulaAmizuka↓. (Bḍ.)

lamazahu, (Ks, Ṣ,) aor _i, (Ṣ,) inf. n. lamozN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He pushed him, or impelled him, or repelled him: (Ks, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) said by AM to be the primary signification: (TA:) and he struck him, or beat him. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmiruhu [means I saw him talking enigmatically with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him: or, accord. to the TA, mulaAmazapN is syn. with mulaAgazapN]. (A, in art. lgz.)

lumazapN One who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also lam-aAzN↓, (so in two copies of the Ṣ, and in a copy of the A,) or lamaAzN↓, like saHaAbN: (Ḳ:) lumazapN is applied to a man and to a woman; for its p is to denote intensiveness, and not the fem. gender: (TA:) humazapN and lumazapN signify the same; (ISk, Zj, Ḳ;) i. e., one who speaks evil of others, or does so in their absence, though it may be with truth; (yagotaAbuhumo; and this may mean [who detracts by making signs] with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head; TA;) and defames them; (ISk, Zj, TA;) or one who often goes about with calumny, a separater of companions and friends: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA:) and lam-aAzN↓, like Xad-aAdN, a frequent, or habitual, calumniator, or slanderer: (TA:) or humazapN and lumazapN differ in signification; the latter signifying one who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, thee to thy face; and the former, one who does so in thine absence; (Ḳ;) and Lth says the like: (TA:) or the latter, one who speaks evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbN,) behind the back; and the former, one who does so to the face: or the latter, one who speaks against the lineages of men; and the former, one who speaks against the characters of men: or the latter, [one who reproaches] with the tongue; and the former, with the eye: or the reverse: (Ḳ [but omitted in the CK], TA:) or the latter signifies one who excites discord, or animosity, between two persons. (TA.) See also humazapN. And see the Ksh and Bḍ in civ. 1.
lamaAzN: see lumazapN.
lam-aAzN [One who makes frequent signs with the eye, or the like: fem. with p {lam-aAapzN}: see one ex. voce ram-aAzN].
See also lumazapN, in two places.
laAmizN act. part. n. of 1.
lum-aAzN [its pl.] Persons who speak evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbuwna,) in their presence. (IAạr, TA.)

1. lamasahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yalomusu} (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yalomisu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. lamosN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) He felt it; or touched it; syn. mas-ahu: (IAạr, Az, IDrd, El-Fárábee, A, Mṣb, TA:) or he felt it, or touched it, (mas-ahu,) with his hand: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he put his hand to it: (Mṣb:) or he felt it with his hand for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; syn. jas-ahu: (M, TA:) and laAmasahu↓ is syn. with lamasahu, (M, TA,) or maAs-ahu: (A:) lamosN and mas-N both signify the perceiving by means of the exterior of the external skin: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or they are nearly alike: (TA:) [generally, like the English words feeling and touching, respectively:] or the former is, originally, [the feeling] with the hand for the purpose of knowing the feel (mas-) of a thing: (IDrd, Mṣb:) or, with the hand, it is the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing here and there: (Lth, TA:) mulaAmasapN is the same as mumaAs-apN (Ḳ, TA) with the hand; as also lamosN: (TA:) or a distinction is to be made between them; for it is said that lamosN is sometimes the feeling, or touching a thing with a thing; and is sometimes [for] the knowledge of a thing, though there be no touching (mas-) of substance upon substance; whereas mlAmsp is mostly mutual feeling or touching,, &c., being the act of two. (IAạr in TA.)

[Hence,] lamasahaA, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yalomusu} (M) [and _i, as implied in the Ḳ], inf. n. lamosN, (Ṣ, M,) ‡ Inivit eam; (I’Ab, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) scil. mulierem; (A, Mṣb;) puellam; (Ḳ;) as also laAmasahaA↓, (M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. mulaAmasapN (I’Ab, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and limaAsN: (I’Ab, Mṣb:) and † he kissed her; by doing which, as well as by the former, one renders necessary the performance of the ablution termed wDwC. ('Abd-Allah Ibn-ʼAmr, Ibn-Mesʼood.)

[Hence also,] lamasahu, aor. _u {yalomusu} [and _i], (A, TA,) inf. n. lamosN, (IDrd, Mṣb, TA,) ‡ He sought, [as though by feeling,] or sought for or after, it, namely, a thing, (IDrd, Mṣb, TA,) in any manner; (IDrd, Mṣb;) [as, for instance, by asking, or demanding;] as also Altmshu↓, (Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ, TA,) [which is more common,] and tlm-shu↓: (M, TA:) or this last signifies he sought it, or sought for or after it, repeatedly, or time after time. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, Oulomuso liI fulaAnFA (A, TA) ‡ Seek thou for me such a one. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [lxxii. 8,] relating the words of the jinn, or genii, Uin-aA lamasonaA Als-amaMCa, (Ḳ,* TA,*) ‡ Verily we sought to reach heaven: or to learn the news thereof: (Bḍ:) or to hear by stealth what was said therein: (Jel:) or we laboured, or strove, after (EaAlajonaA) the secrets of heaven, and sought to hear them by stealth. (Ḳ.) And in a trad., mano salaka TariyqFA yalotamisu↓ bihi EilomFA ‡ Whoso pursueth a way whereby he seeketh after knowledge, or science. (TA.) And in another, of ʼÁïsheh, faQlotamasotu↓ EiqodiI ‡ And I sought for my necklace. (TA.)

lamasa AlbaSara, aor. _u {yalomusu}, ‡ It took away the sight. (A, TA.) And the same, or, accord. to one relation of a trad., Altmshu↓, † It took away quickly, and destroyed, the sight; said there of certain serpents: or the meaning is, † it aimed at the eye with its bite: and lamasa Eayonahu is said to signify [† he, or it, put out his eye,] the same as samala. (TA.)

3. lAmshu, inf. n. mulaAmasapN and limaAsN: for its proper signification, see 1, in three places. [Hence,] bayoEu AlmulaAmasapi, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and bayoEu All-imaAsi, (Mgh,) or AlmulaAmasapu fiI AlbayoEi, (Ḳ,) A mode of bargaining, which consists in saying, When thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, or I feel, or touch, thy garment, (A, Ḳ,) or when, (Mgh,) or if, (Mṣb,) I feel, or touch, thy garment, and thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or when I feel, or touch, the thing to be sold, (Ṣ,) the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) between us, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) for such a sum: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ḥaneefeh, in thy saying, I will sell to thee this commodity for such a sum, and when I feel, or touch, thee, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded; or in the purchaser's saying the like: (Mgh:) or, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) as in the Sunan of Aboo-Dáwood, (Mgh,) in purchasing a commodity on the condition of feeling it (M, Mgh,* Ḳ,*) behind a garment or piece of cloth, (Ḳ,) without seeing it, (M, Ḳ,) or spreading it out and turning it over and examining it: (Mgh:) or on the condition that the feeling it with the hand shall cut one off from the choice of returning it: (TA:) the mode of bargaining thus termed is forbidden. (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb.)
For a tropical signification of the verb, see 1.
4. OalomisoniI AljaAriyapa Permit thou me to feel, or touch, the girl. (A, TA.)
OalomisoniI QmoraOapF ‡ Marry thou to me a woman. (A, TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
8: see 1, in four places.

lamuwsN A she-camel of whose fatness one doubts; (O, TṢ, Ḳ;) on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád; (TA;) i. q. XakuwkN and DabuwvN: (A, TA:) or of whose hump one doubts, whether there be in her fat or not; wherefore it is felt: (M, L:) pl. lumusN. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] ‡ One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; syn. daEiI-N: (Ḳ:) or in whose grounds of pretention to respect is a fault, or taint. (A, Ḳ.)
lamiysN A woman soft to the feel, or touch; lay-inapu Almalomasi. (Ḳ.)
lamaAsapN, (M,) lumaAsapN, (Ṣ,) or both, (TA,) † A want: (IAạr, Ṣgh:) or a moderate, or middling, want. (Ṣ, M, O, L.)
lamuwsapN A road, or way: so called because he who has lost his way seeks it in order to find the track of the travellers. (Ḳ,* TA.)

laAmisN act. part. n. of 1. (Mṣb, &c.) One says, of a woman who commits adultery, or fornication, or acts viciously, falaAnapu laA tarud-u yada laAmisK, (A, TA,) or laA tamonaEu yada laAmisK, (Ḳ,) but the latter is at variance with the written authorities, the former being the phrase commonly known, (TA,) [properly signifying, Such a woman does not repel the hand of a feeler;] meaning, ‡ such a woman commits adultery, or fornication, and acts viciously, (Ḳ, TA,) not repelling from herself any one who desires of her that he may lie with her; (TA;) and she is suspected of easiness, or compliance, (Ḳ, TA,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her: (TA:) or the meaning is, such a woman gives, of her husband's property, what is sought, or demanded, from her; and this is more probably meant in a trad. in which a man is related to have said thus of his wife; because Moḥammad directed him to retain her, and did not require him to divorce her. (TA.) The like said of a man, (Ḳ,) fulaAnN laA yarud-u yada laAmisK, (A, Mṣb,) means, ‡ Such a man has in him no force of resistance, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) nor care of what is sacred, or inviolable. (TA.)
malomasN [A place that is felt, or touched: and it may also be an inf. n.: see lamiysN]. (Ḳ.)

UikaAfN malomuwsu AlOaHonaMCi ‡ An ass's saddle, or pad, of which the curved pieces of wood have been felt with the hands until they have become even: (M:) or of which any unevenness and prominence that was therein has been pared off (Lth, T, A, Ḳ) by the passing of the hand over it, (Lth, T,) or of the hands. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. lamaZa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yalomuZu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. lamoZN, (Ṣ, M,) He sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) after eating: (TA:) and he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also tlm-Z↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in both senses: (Ḳ:) you say also tlm-Zt↓ AlHay-apu ‡ The serpent put forth its tongue, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) like as the eater puts it forth and wipes with it his lip: (Ṣ, TA:) or the former verb and ↓the latter signify he took with his tongue what remained in the mouth after eating: (M:) or he sought leisurely and gradually after the taste, and tasted time after time: (M, Ḳ:) or ↓the latter signifies he tasted time after time; as also tmT-q: or he moved about his tongue in his mouth after eating, as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains of the food between his teeth; whereas tmT-q signifies he smacked his lips: (T:) or tlm-Z↓ signifies he sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food between his teeth after eating: or he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips. (Mgh.) [Hence the saying] maA zaAla fulaAnN yatalam-aZu↓ bicikorihi ‡ [Such a one ceased not to busy his tongue with mentioning him, or it]. (TA.)
lamaZa AlmaMCa, inf. n. lamoZN, He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. lm-Zhu, inf. n. talomiyZN; (TA;) or lamaZahu↓; (M as quoted in the TT [being there written without teshdeed; and both seem to be correct;]) He gave him something to taste; he fed him with something whereby to content or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the morning-meal; syn. caw-aqahu and lam-ajahu, (M, TA,) both of which are alike. (TA.) You say also, lam-iZo fulaAnFA lumaAZapF [Give thou to such a one, to eat,] something which he may taste time after time, or after eating which he may move about his tongue in his mouth as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains thereof between his teeth. (T.)
And [hence,] lm-Zhu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and lamaZahu↓; (M, Ḳ;) ‡ He gave to him (M, Ḳ, TA) somewhat (M, TA) of his right, or due. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
4. AlmZhu He put the water upon the edge of his lips, (M,) or upon his lips, or lip. (Ḳ, accord. to different copies.)
And hence UilomaAZN is used to signify ‡ The act of piercing, or thrusting, feebly [with a spear or the like]. (M,* TA.)
5: see 1, in six places.
8. AltmZhu He ate it: (ISk, Ṣ, M, A:) or he threw it quickly into his mouth. (O, Ḳ.)
9. AlmZ-, inf. n. UilomiZaAZN, He (a horse) had a lumoZap, or whiteness upon his lower lip. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
lamaZN: see lumoZapN, in two places.

lumoZapN A whiteness in the lower lip of a horse, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) not being a part of the [whiteness termed] gur-ap; (M;) as also lamaZN↓: (M, Ḳ:) also the former, a gur-ap which descends so that it enters into the mouth of a horse, and so that he removes with it what has remained in his mouth after eating: and ↓the latter, somewhat white in the lip of a beast of carriage, not passing beyond the place where the lip closes: (M:) or the former, a whiteness upon both the lips, only. (M, Ḳ.) Also, Somewhat of whiteness in the fore leg of a horse, or in his hind leg, upon the OaXoEar [or hair which surrounds the hoof.] (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And A small spot (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of white: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and contr. of black, in the heart. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., that faith begins like a lumoZap in the heart; (T, Ṣ;) and as faith increases, so the latter increases. (T.) And that hypocrisy in the heart is a black lmZp, and faith is a white lmZp; and as either increases, so the lmZp increases. (M. TA.)
Also, ‡ A small quantity of clarified butter, which one takes with the finger, (Ḳ, TA,) like a walnut: mentioned by Z and Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)

lamaAZN A thing which one tastes, (Ḳ, TA), and with which one moves about the tongue in the mouth. (TA.) You say, maA lahu lamaAZN He has not anything to taste, (Ḳ, TA,), &c. (TA.) And maA cuqotu lamaAZFA I have not tasted anything. (Ṣ) And Xariba AlmaMCa lamaAZFA He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*) [See also what next follows.]
